Leoncio works selling medicinal products like herbs, creams, liquids, essences and other articles. The loan he is asking for is to purchase creams that are highly demanded in the summer months, and he wishes to acquire these creams in large quantities in order to obtain important buyer discounts.

Translated from Spanish by David Hou, Princeton University Language Project volunteer.

El señor Leoncio E. tiene 36 años, vive en pareja y tiene dos hijos de 6 y 2 años respectivamente.

Ellos viven juntos en su casa que construyeron en el terreno de su suegro hace mas de tres años, casa que lograron obtener gracias al sacrificio de ambos. Leoncio posee un local de ventas de remedios naturales y donde su señora ayuda también a atender, ya que es un local que posee gran cantidad de clientela.

Leoncio se dedica a vender productos medicinales, por ejemplo: hierbas, cremas, líquidos, esencias y otros artículos. El crédito que solicita es para la compra de mercaderías (cremas) que tienen mucha salida en el verano, y desea adquirir mercaderías en grandes cantidades de modo a obtener importantes descuentos en las compras.

loans.use: Purchase of natural remedies and various herbs and ointments.

loans.name: Rashid

texts.en: This young man was born in 1985. He is single and lives in Khudat town. Rashid has 2 years of experience in this business. He buys the cattle to fatten for sale. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy 2 head of cattles for improving his business.

loans.use: To buy 2 cattles

loans.name: Bumi

texts.en: Bumi A. is a mother of 4 and is 42 years old; she lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She has been a member of LAPO for the past 2 years. She sells provisions, foodstuffs and drinks. She has been in business since 1992. She needs the loan of $450 to buy more provisions, foodstuffs and drinks for sale.

loans.use: To buy more provisions, foodstuffs and drinks

loans.name: Putu Purnamayanti

texts.id:
Putu Purnamayanti has been married for 15 years. Her husband is a security guard working for a private company. Putu Purnamyanti's husband makes about $88 per month. Putu Purnamayanti has 2 children, the eldest, Gusti Putu Purwanjaya, is 13 year old and currently in junior high school. THe second child, Gusti Kade Aroprasetya is 9 year old and is still in primary school. Putu Purnamayanti currently is working with her own kiosk business that sells various traditional Balinese food and snacks and local favorites. She started the business using her savings. Currently, Purnamayanti is applying to obtain a loan for business expansion from DINARI. Everyday, Purnamayant spends about $11 to purchase her goods to sell, and gets about $17 in revenue, so she gets $6 profit daily. Putu Purnamayanti is going to be grateful if she can get the loan so she can expand her business.

Translated form Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Putu Purnamayanti berkeluarga sudah 15 tahun . Suaminya bekerja sebagai seorang Satpam di sebuah perusahaan swasta. Penghasilan suami Purnamayanti per bulan Rp. 800,000,-. Putu Purnamayanti memiliki 2 orang anak yang pertama bernama Gusti Putu Purwanjaya berumur 13 tahun duduk di bangku SMP. Anak yang nomor 2 bernama Gusti Kade Ariprasetya umur 9 tahun duduk dibangku SD. Putu Purnamayanti saat ini sedang menekuni usaha warung yang khusus menjual makanan tradisional seperti berbagai macam kue khas Bali. Selain itu juga berbagai macam makanan dan minuman ringan yang sangat digemari oleh warga sekitar tempat tinggalnya. Untuk modal awal Purnamayanti mempergunakan tabungan mereka. Sekarang ini Purnamayanti mendapatkan tambahan modal usaha dari DINARI yang dipergunakan untuk modal berdagang. Setiap hari Purnamayanti menghabiskan modal warung Rp.100,000,-dan pendapatan kotornya Rp.150.000,- jadi keuntungan bersihnya Rp.50,000,- Putu Purnamayanti sangat bersyukur ada pinjaman modal dari Dinari sehingga ia bisa mengembangkan usahanya.

loans.use: Renovate kiosk and increase product offering

loans.name: Gustavo Antonio

texts.es:
Mr. Gustavo García is a hard-working and determined 53 year-old. He lives in Batahola Norte together with his wife and only son. Gustavo has taught his 16 year-old son the value of work, the importance of education, and family values since the time his son was young. For the past 8 years they have run a dining room in which they sell food to the people who live and work nearby. The business began in their house by selling 10 plates of food daily. Today they sell more than 60 plates daily. Gustavo’s success and business growth has come thanks to the support of his wife and the part-time assistance of his son, who helps with the business after school.

Gustavo is asking for a loan in order to purchase basic grains, fruits, vegetables and soft drinks in bulk. The vacations surrounding Holy Week are coming and that is a good time for his business, and thus he doesn’t want to lose the opportunity for sales. With a little more effort and dedication Gustavo dreams of seeing his small dining room become a successful restaurant that his son can take over after finishing his university studies.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

El señor Gustavo G. es un hombre trabajador y esforzado de 53 años de edad que habita en Batahola Norte junto a su esposa y un solo hijo de 16 años de edad a quien le ha enseñado desde pequeño el valor del trabajo, amor al estudio y valores familiares. Desde hace 8 años tienen un comedor en donde venden comida a los que habitan y trabajan alrededor, este negocio lo iniciaron en su casa vendiendo 10 platos diarios de comida hoy vende mas de 60 platos diarios, este éxito y crecimiento ha sido gracias al apoyo de su esposa y aporte de medio tiempo de su hijo quien del colegio se integra al negocio de la familia. Solicita un crédito para prepararse a comprar granos básicos, frutas, verduras y gaseosas en mayor cantidad ya que la en las vacaciones de Semana Santa es una buena época para su negocio que no quiere desaprovechar, con un poco mas de esfuerzo y dedicación don Gustavo sueña con ver su local de comedor a pequeño Restaurante y dejar a su hijo a cargo cuando termine una carrera Universitaria.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for making meals

loans.name: Arshad's Group

texts.en: Arshad B. is the wife of Jalal Din and resides with her family in Lahore, a big city in Pakistan. Her other family members are two daughters and two boys. Both of her boys could not attend school due to various financial problems but she has now managed to send her daughters to school. Her husband works at a convenience store and both her boys supplies construction supplies. Sabra J. wants to buy CDs for their video centre; Shabana I. will also invest in her business; Azra M. needs to buy a new horse for their horse cart and Sadia B.’s husband deals in spare parts.

loans.use: expand construction supplies business

loans.name: Sy Mohamed Ousman

texts.fr:
Mr. Sy Mohamed Ousmane S. was born November 24, 1969 in Lomé. He is a married father of three children. He resells staple goods in his store, ETS SY. He started this business in 1989 in the Aguiar neighborhood, near the main market in Lomé. His long-standing presence in the neighborhood and the quality of his service has earned him the trust of his customers. In his store, he also normally sells milk, canned goods and soap, and he has telephone booths available to his customers. This first loan he is requesting will allow him to buy 40 boxes of milk and 20 boxes of canned goods.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Monsieur S. Sy Mohamed Ousmane est né le 24 novembre 1969 à Lomé. Il est marié et père de trois (3) enfants. Il est revendeur des produits de premières nécessités dans son magasin ETS SY. Il a commencé cette activité depuis 1989 dans le quartier Aguiar près du grand marché de Lomé. Son ancienneté dans le quartier et la qualité de ses services lui font gagner la confiance de ses clients. Il vend généralement dans son magasin, du lait, des boîtes de conserves, des savons et met également des cabines téléphoniques à la disposition de ses clients. Le premier crédit qu’il sollicite lui permettra d’acheter 40 cartons de lait et 20 cartons de boîte de conserve

loans.use: Purchase of 40 boxes of milk

loans.name: Azra's Group

texts.en:
Azra baji is the wife of M. Y. and lives in a small city named Burewala in Pakistan. ( Baji is an Urdu term meaning 'elder sister'.) They have a two-room brick house. Her husband is a driver and drives a three wheel vehicle called auto-rickshaw. She is requesting a loan for her husband so that he can purchase another rickshaw and expand his business.

She has four other women in her loan group. Naeem baji wants loan for her Pan shop; Shahnaz baji has a need to funds for her video center; Seema baji wants a loan for her embroidery business and Saima baji wants funding to expand her furniture business.

The loan will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase an additional auto-rickshaw for business expansion

loans.name: Mougnou (Patience) Group

texts.fr:
The members of Mougnou group, with an average age of 30 and 6 children on average, live in traditional extended families in the village of Sikouna 1, Sub-prefecture of Fana (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali).

The group sells various items: cigarettes, tea, clothing, condiments (smoked fish, dried fish, spices, etc.)

They are essentially bound by ties of neighborhood, similar age, and friendship.

The solidarity of the group being firm, the members of Mougnou have decided to work together with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso which has approved their first group loan this month.

They do their purchasing from wholesalers who come from Bamako and Ségou to market days in Marka coungo. They sell their goods either from home or at the market or as ambulant salespeople. Their sales are generally retail and on a cash basis.

The members of the group intend to buy 25 kg of fish, 5 kg of spices, packets of tea, a carton of cigarettes and some clothing items. With this loan, they hope to make a profit of 7500 FCFA which will be used essentially for reinvesting in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Les membres du groupe Mougnou avec une moyenne d’age de âgé de 30 ans et 6 enfants vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Sikouna 1 sous préfecture de Fana (Région de Koulikoro République du Mali.)

Le groupe fait le commerce d’articles divers : cigarettes, thé, habillements, et les condiments alimentaires (poisson fumé, séché, épices etc.)

Elles sont essentiellement unies par des liens de voisinage, de groupe d’age et d’amitié.

La solidarité du groupe ne souffrant d’aucune faille les membres de Mougnou ont décidé ensemble de collaborer avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso qui leurs a octroyé leur premier prêt de groupe ce mois ci.

L’approvisionnement de ce groupe se fait exclusivement auprès des grossistes venant de Bamako et Ségou les jours de foire de Marka coungo. Elles revendent leurs articles suivant les cas à la maison soit au marché soit de façon ambulante .Les ventes de ce groupe se font généralement en détail au comptant.

Les membres du groupe comptent acheter 25kg de poissons 5kg d’épices des paquets de thé une cartouche de cigarettes et quelques habits. Elles espèrent réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice de 7500FCFAqui servira essentiellement à l’investissement dans l’activité.

Ces femmes de Mougnou envisagent devenir des grossistes.

loans.use:
purchase of various items for re-sale

Achat d’articles divers

loans.name: Sayaad Shah

texts.en:
Sayaad Shah is 43 years old. He is married and is the father of 5 children. He lives in district 15 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He has a small retail shop that he started 6 years ago in Kabul. Still he is busy. Sayaad Shah is a very hard worker. He always wants to become strong in his business. He loves his business.

Shah wants to enlarge his business so he has requested an individual loan to complete his stock and buy more to sell such as baskets, shampoo, and Pepsi, to attract more customers and make a good monthly income for his family. He is sure that he can help his family after using this loan.

He is happy that, with this small loans process, he can expand his business. He hopes to have a big store in the next 3 years. He wants to continue his partnership with both AFSG and Kiva. He would like to thank Kiva lenders who help people in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell such as baskets, shampoo, and Pepsi

loans.name: Farmer Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Vat K. C. is the leader of a group of four in Kampong Svay Village in Kandal Province. She is a farmer who now does not have enough money to buy rice seeds to cultivate rice. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose.

Her husband, Mr. Soth Sengleang, is a house constructor who can only make a small income to support his family. Mrs. Vat K. C. is 44 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the three remaining are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds to cultivate rice in her field

loans.name: Carmela

texts.en:
Carmela R. V. is a member of the community bank, Anabella. She lives in Ayacucho, Peru, with her two children (aged 21 and 20). Both of her children are studying at the local university, while her husband lives in Spain. She is an independent distributor of DeBelle cosmetics. Carmela also helps her friend, Lydia, when she has catering events.

Carmela will invest her loan of 1000 soles into her cosmetics business by purchasing nail polish, blush, eye-liners, lipsticks and lotions, so she will always have fresh samples to sell to her clients. With her savings, she would like to keep moving forward and be able to be her own woman, without the need to rely on her husband. She also has been saving to help her children stay in school and finish their studies.

loans.use: To purchase nail polish, blush, eye-liners, lipsticks and lotions for her cosmetics business.

loans.name: Rosa Alina

texts.es: La señora Rosa Alina tiene la edad de 33 años habita en Reparto Juan Ramón Padilla ubicado en el mucipio de Ticuantepe junto a su esposo eh hija , el esposo de doña Alina es carpintero tiene su propio taller al igual que doña Alina tiene su taller de costura que con apoyo de AFODENIC y sus propios esfuerzos ah logrado mantenerlo  , los sueños de doña Alina es lograr tener una tienda de confecciones y sacar adelante y darle mejor condición de vida a su hija , ella solicita nuevamente el financiamiento de Afodenic , para incrementar su inventario y aprovechar la época de fiesta de Navidad .
texts.en:
Rosa Alina is 33 years old and lives with her husband and daughter at Reparto Juan Ramon Padilla located in the city of Ticuantepe. Her husband is a carpenter and has his own workshop. Alina also has a sewing shop that she obtained through the support of AFODENIC; through her own efforts, she has been able to maintain this shop. Alina's dreams are to acquire a sewing store, move forward, and give better living conditions to her daughter. She requests this new loan from AFODENIC in order to increase her inventory and take advantage of the christmas season.

Translated from Spanish by Brittany Thatcher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fabric and sewing materials

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Maribel’s family lives in Malamag West. She is married to Benito, a farmer, and is blessed with three children who motivate them to work hard. Their backyard is planted with vegetables, which gives her an average daily income of P150. She does not have to go to the market to purchase vegetables because she has ready supplies in her backyard.
	
She is always seen walking in her neighborhood with her basket filled with different varieties of vegetable.  She dreams of having her own tribike (a small bicycle with a carriage or sidecar) to be used as a rolling store. This will lessen her burden of carrying the vegetables she sells. She will use her loan of P3,000 to increase her capital and to buy the tribike.
 
Her ultimate goals in life are to live simply and provide for her children’s education.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Fidela

texts.es:
La señora Fidela es socia del Banco Comunal “Virgen D. Cancharani” D. la provincia D. Puno, en el departamento D. Puno. Tiene 56 años D. edad, es casada y madre D. 3 hijos. Con su primer préstamo D. S/. 500 compró triciclos. Tiene casi 3 años  trabajando con el banco. Nos cuenta que compró triciclos y tiene locales alquilados en su casa.
Con este préstamo D. S/.1500 que pagará en 6 cuotas comprará más triciclos y aumentar su negocio.
Fidela desea continuar trabajando para tener una librería.
texts.en:
Fidela is a member of the Virgin of Cancharani Communal Bank in the province and district of Puno. She is 56 years old, married, and the mother of three. With her first loan of ~$165, she bought tricycles. She has been working with this bank for almost three years. She tells us that she bought tricycles and rents rooms in her home. With this loan of $500, which will be paid back in six installments, she will buy more tricycles to expand her business. Fidela wants to continue working so she can have a bookstore.

Translated from Spanish by Olivia Engkvist, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase tricycles

loans.name: Juan Jose

texts.es:
Juan José E. M. tiene 65 años de edad su estado civil es soltero, Don Juan tiene 1 hijo de la edad de 40 años y cursa el 4 año de secundaria de nivel superior y este a la misma ves trabaja hay que resaltar que su hijo estudia de noche ya que el no pudo estudiar por lo que tenia que trabajar y hoy en día esta estudiando, sus propósitos son de mantener activo su negocio activo y así poder pagar los compromisos contraídos con Fundación León 2000 que no le gustaría quedar mal con su record sus sueños son de comprar otra unidad de taxi para seguir trabajando y además dejarle este negocio a su hijo ya que le beneficiaria para el futuro ya que este seria otro medio de ingresos para el y su familia sus deseos son seguir trabajando para que de esta forma pueda obtener su propia cooperativa de taxi y así dejar de trabajar ya que se siente muy cansado por su edad por lo que este seria su mayor deseo.

La actividad económica es el servicio de taxi, la ubicación de su negocio es de forma ambulante por lo que tiene que recorrer las diferentes calles en busca de pasajeros, el tiempo que tiene de poseer este negocio es de 15 años, Don Juan inicio este negocio por cuenta propia y con su dinero como mecánico y además joyero por lo que ambas profesiones las practico por lo que estas no le proporcionaban el ingreso necesario para su familia y decide incursionar en un nuevo negocio como es el servicio de taxi ya que los trabajos que tenia anteriormente no le cubría  lo necesario para los gastos de su hogar y es como decide mas tarde incursionar a otro negocio como lo es el servicio de taxi por lo que  no cuenta con otra actividad económica y este negocio le gusta y es así como decide quedarse con este negocio por lo que ahora necesita financiamiento para capital de trabajo  ya que necesita comprar amortiguadores y chequeo general de del taxi para que sus clientes no peligren con el servicio que le brinda.
texts.en:
Juan José E. M. is sixty-five years old and single. Juan has one son, who is forty and in his fourth year of advanced studies and working at the same time. It is worth highlighting that his son studies at night -- Juan himself could not study when he had to work. These days he is studying. Juan hopes to maintain his business and in this way pay back Fundación León 2000, because he would not like to develop a bad record with them. He dreams of adding another taxi unit to his business, and of leaving this business to his son, who would benefit in the future, even though it would be an investment for him and his family. Juan’s son dreams of having his own taxi business; then Juan could stop working, since he is very tired by his age – this is their biggest dream. Juan runs a taxi service. His business travels, because he must drive around the streets looking for passengers. Juan has had this business for fifteen years. He started it of his own account with money he had earned from being a mechanic and a jeweler (he was both). He decided to start a taxi business since he could not count on the jobs he was working to cover household costs well. He likes this business, which is why he has chosen to stay with it and ask for a loan to purchase shock absorbers and general car servicing for the taxis so that his customers are not put in danger by the service he provides.

Translated from Spanish by Hannah Lily, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Arth

texts.en:
Arth R., 59, is married and lives with two of her children in the Takeo province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about US$1 each day and are supported by one child working in the garment factory.

The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Arth R. included. To help generate more income to support the family, Mrs. Arth R. has an idea to take out a loan to purchase a motorbike for her son to operate a moto-taxi business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Gulchehra

texts.en:
M. Gulchehra lives in the B. Gafurov region of Tajikistan. She is married with four children. As with many rural women, she doesn't have a specialized education but she is experienced in livestock so she started taking care of home animals when she was a girl and helping her mother.

Today Gulchehra has her own family and owns livestock -- two cows and four rams. She makes milk and sour products and sells them in local bazaar. Gulchehra applies to Kiva for the business support loan of 1,200 STJ for six months to purchase special milk-making equipment. It will permit her to increase milk making and to use modern methods of milk making.

Gulshehra thanks Kiva for its support and wishes all the best.

loans.use: Purchase special milk-making equipment

loans.name: Saing

texts.en: Saing K., 52, is a widowed mother of four children who are single. Three of them are employed as local farmers and the other one studies in the secondary school. K. currently cultivates rice crops, which she can plant every two seasons a year, including dry season and rainy season. Beside this, she raises a few pigs from her home. K. is applying for a loan to build a pigpen and to buy more piglets to raise. The family resides in Pursat Province, Cambodia.

loans.use: To build a pigpen and to buy more piglets to raise.

loans.name: Maria Avelina

texts.es:
La señora María Avelina G. D. ValverD. tiene 50 años y pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres del Mañana, vive en el distrito D. Agallpampa en la provincia D. Otuzco en el departamento D. La Libertad Perú.
Estudió primaria completa, la concluyo D. 16 años, debido a bajos recursos económicos no continuo estudiando. A los 17 años se casó y tiene 4 hijos.
Con su primer crédito D. 300 soles devuelto en 4 cuotas compro animales para engorD., luego los volvió a vender por mayor precio.
Con este crédito D. 800 soles que devolverá en 6 cuotas comprará animales D. corral para engordarlos y volverlos a vender a mayor precio.
Avelina sueña con tener un buen capital para poder trabajar cada día mejor.
texts.en:
Mrs. María Avenlina G. D. ValverD., 50, belongs to the Mujeres D. Mañana community bank. She lives in the Agallpampa district in the Otuzco province in the La Libertad department of Perú. She completed primary school, but she stopped going to school when she was 16 due to low economic resources. She married at 17, and she has 4 children. With her first loan of 300 PEN, which she repaid in 4 payments, she bought animals to fatten and resell at a better price. She will use this loan of 800 PEN, which she will repay in 6 payments, to buy small farm animals to fatten and resell at a better price. Avelina dreams of having good capital to be able to work better every day

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy small farm animals

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena A. is forty eight years old. She is divorced and has given birth to four children, one son and three daughters. She says that all of her children are currently out of basic school.  She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a farming/commercial town named Takorase, which is near Akim Oda in the eastern region of Ghana.

Abena is a trader. She trades second hand textiles – clothes for both men and women and also bed sheets. She procures bales of textiles from Accra and sells them in her community by hawking. She says she also treks to other towns to sell on their market days. Abena has been in this business for eight years and desires to expand her business. This will allow her to sponsor her children to attend higher levels of schooling.

loans.use: To procure second hand textiles

loans.name: Shazia Yousaf Masih Group

texts.en:
Shazia Y. M. is the group leader of other four women. They all live in the city of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. They are hard-working and are satisfied with their struggle. Shazia manages a cot-knitting business. She earns income from the orders that she gets from the community. Shazia baji is applying for a loan to buy wood for her husband’s wood-selling business.

Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy seasonal vegetables for her vegetable-selling business. Kosar baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes. Razia baji wants a loan to pay the remaining installment of her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Shazia baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan and the loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy wood to sell

loans.name: Emma

texts.es:
La señora Emma, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Shatojinas Laboriosas”, vive en el Jr. Sargento Lores S/Nº, Provincia El Dorado, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 48 años y es madre de 06 hijos, 03 que aun dependen de ella.

Viviendo cerca a un lugar donde hay mucho movimiento, Emma decidió vender sus comidas preparadas y anticuchos en la Plaza de su Distrito, ella nos cuenta que a diario tiene muy buenas ventas, por la sazón rica que le da a sus preparados y tiene mucha acogida. 
En la actualidad, continúa con el mismo negocio, y esta muy contenta con su trabajo que realiza día a día, a partir de las 6:00 de la tarde. Es ella quien personalmente atiende a sus clientes con el carisma que le caracteriza. 

Con el préstamo de S/ 2,000.00, desea invertirlo comprando insumos para la preparación diaria de sus alimentos como arroz en kilos, azúcar; aceites en galones, pollos en javas y también  algunos utensilios  para implementar su negocio y dar una mejor atención a sus clientes. 

Se siente llena de vida y con ganas de seguir adelante aun, tiene muchos sueños y metas en su vida, como implementar su propio restaurant en un local bien acondicionado y al mismo tiempo también agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  en iniciar su negocio.
texts.en:
Ms. Emma P. is a member of the “Shatojinas Laboriosas” Microfinance Institute. She is a 48-year-old married mother of 6 children, 3 of whom are still her dependents.

Living near a bustling area, Emma decided to sell prepared foods and marinated grilled meat on skewers (anticuchos) at her district’s main square. She states that daily sales are good because of the delicious flavor that she gives to her dishes, and because her business is so welcoming.

She currently owns this same business, and she is satisfied with the job that she does day by day, starting at 6pm. She personally attends to her customers with the charisma that she is noted for.

She would like to invest this 2,000.00 PEN loan in purchasing ingredients for her daily food preparation, such as rice by the kilogram, sugar, gallons of cooking oil, chicken, and utensils to restock her business and provide better customer service. She feels alive and has the desire to keep moving forward. She has many dreams and goals in her life, such as launching her own restaurant in a well-equipped business space. She gives thanks to the Manuela Ramos Movement for helping her start her business.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase food preparation ingredients (rice, sugar, cooking oil, chicken)

loans.name: Anabel

texts.es: Anabel tiene 29 años, vive con sus padres en la casa de ellos. Se dedica a atender su propio consultorio dental todos los días de la semana de acuerdo a los horarios de visita de sus clientes, que por lo general son hasta los domingos en las tardes y sólo descansa los martes de cada semana. Realiza extracciones de dientes, curaciones diversas y otros tratamientos dentales y lo hace con mucho profesionalismo por lo que sus clientes van en aumento. Anabel está muy entusiasmada por la labor que está realizando y planea seguir con este proyecto profesional hasta tener una clínica odontológica. Es la tercera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP, está muy contenta de ser parte del banco comunal que integra y renueva su compromiso de seguir adelante con mucha responsabilidad. El dinero que está solicitando será invertido en la compra de materiales odontológicos que necesita para su consultorio.
texts.en:
Anabel, 29, lives with her parents in their house. She works in her own dental office every day of the week according to the schedule for seeing patients. Generally she is open until Sunday afternoons. Her only day off is every Tuesday. She extracts teeth, cures diverse problems, and performs other dental treatments. Because she does so very professionally, the number of patients she has is increasing. Anabel is very enthusiastic about the work she is doing, and she plans to continue on this professional path until she has her own dental clinic. This is the third time she has had a loan with MFP. She is very happy to be part of her community bank. She renews her promise to continue on very responsibly. The money she is asking for will be used to buy dental materials that she needs for her office.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy dental materials

loans.name: Edith

texts.es: Edith tiene 34 años, vive con su esposo y sus 2 hijos de 14 y 10 años en su casa propia. Desde hace un año se dedica al transporte y a la ganadería. Tiene dos autos, uno lo maneja su esposo y para el otro ha contratado a un chofer, ambos cubren diariamente la ruta interprovincial de su zona y no tienen un día específico de descanso, salvo que se necesite hacer un mantenimiento técnico a los carros. Este trabajo le ha permitido solventar los gastos familiares y ahorrar para poder adquirir otro carro en un futuro cercano. Esta es la 8va oportunidad que tiene un préstamo con MFP, está muy contenta por su progreso, por lo que continuará trabajando en su banco comunal, ya que disfruta de cada momento que pasa con sus compañeros. El dinero que viene solicitando será invertido en el pago del mantenimiento técnico de sus 2 carros.
texts.en:
Edith is 34 years old. She and her husband live in their own house, along with their two children, ages 14 and 10. For the last year, she has worked in transportation. They have two cars. Her husband drives one of them, and for the other she has hired a driver. Each day, both cars cover the provincial route of their zone and there is no specific day off, unless they need to do maintenance on the vehicles. This business has enabled them to cover the household costs as well as save for another vehicle in the near future. This is the 8th loan Edith has had from MFP. She is very content with the progress she is making and will continue to work with the communal bank. She also enjoys every moment she spends with the other members of the group. She will use the requested loan to cover maintenance costs on the two vehicles.


Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay for maintenance on the vehicles used in her transportation business.

loans.name: Narzullo

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan
     Нарзулло - мужчина  который занимается откормом и продажей скота. Кроме этого он работает разнорабочим по заказу клиентов. Нарзулло на запрашиваемый кредит хочет закупить несколько коз и баранов. Его жена работает в колхозе, вместо денег с колхоза получает продукты питания. У Нарзулло в данное время есть десять баранов, которые пасутся на пастбище и корова дома. Нарзулло старается увеличить количество своего скота.
texts.en:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand” “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan

Narzullo feeds and sells cattle. Besides that he also does odd jobs by taking orders from customers. Narzullo wants to use the requested loan to buy several goats and sheep. His wife works in a collective farm, she receives food as payment instead of money. At this time Narzullo has ten sheep which are grazing in the field and one cow at home. Narzullo tries to increase the number of his cattle.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Women Of The Valley Group

texts.es:
el grupo Mujeres del Valle esta integrado por 4 mujeres muy luchadoras, a continuacion se detalla las actividades que ellas realizan:

la sra. LEYLA DEL CARMEN M. tiene 4 años de haber iniciado la venta de cosmeticos, la mayoria de sus ventas las lleva a cabo de manera ambulante.- Leyla tomo la desición de dedicarse al comercio para apoyar a su esposo a cubrir en lo que pueda con ciertos gastos del hogar.
Leyla vive en unión libre y es madre de 3 hijos, los cuales dependen de ella y su compañero de hogar.
su prometido se dedica a la agricultura y tambien se dedica a trabajar como labrador en el campo.

la sra. NEYBI SOFIA R. O. tiene 1 año de haber iniciado con la venta de cosmeticos,
vende el producto de manera ambulante en la aldea de Santa Maria, Jamastran.- 
Neybi vivia en unión libre y es madre de 4 hijos de los cuales ya solo 3 dependen de ella; su compañero de hogar tuvo que emigrar para los EE.UU en busca de mejorar su condición de vida y hasta el momento ha logrado, porque con las remesas que el le envia las invierte en mejorar su vivienda,  
de las ganancias que le genera su negocio cubre a un 100% los gastos personales.

la sra. JULIA AMPARO O. tiene 8 años de dedicarse a la venta de comidas, sus clientes permanentes son los agentes policiales, Julia tomo la desición de dedicarse a esta actividad ya que anteriormente contiguo a su casa habia un comedor con atención para todo el público, pero hace 8 años este negocio fue cerrado y mucha gente tenia la costumbre de ir a comer ahi y eso le facilito el poner su negocio ya que practicamente tenia varios clientes fijos.- 
desde entonces doña Julia le vende la comida a los policias.- 
es casada y su esposo se dedica a la agricultura, de ellos dependen 4 hijas mismas que le ayudan 
a la elaboración de comidas.

la sra. YOLANDA MARIBEL M. tiene 4 años de dedicarse a la elaboracion y venta de pan y de golosinas, Yolanda se dedica a hornear 2 veces por semana y la venta de golosinas la lleva a cabo los dias domingos, se va vender las golosinas al campo de futbol.- 
Es madre de 3 hijos los cuales dependen a un 100% de ellos, su esposo labora como labrador en el campo.
con los ingresos que le genera el negocio ella a podido apoyar a su esposo a cubrir ciertos gastos del hogar.

todas ellas necesitan el credito para salir adelante con sus familias.
texts.en:
The Women of the Valley Group (el grupo Mujeres del Valle) is comprised of four women who are strong fighters. What follows are details of the activities they have achieved. Ms. LEYLA DEL CARMEN M. has been selling cosmetics for four years. She carries out the majority of those sells on the street. Leyla decided to go into business to support her companion in covering some of their family expenses. Leyla lives with her partner and has 3 children who depend on her. Her fiance works in agriculture and works as a laborer in the fields. Mrs. NEYBI SOFIA R. O. has been selling cosmetics for 1 year. She sells cosmetics on the street in her village of Santa Maria, Jamastranh. Neybi is a mother of 4 children, 3 of whom depend on her still. Her companion had to immigrate to the USA in search of a better living, and up until now he has achieved it. With the earnings he sends home to her, she has been able to invest in improving their living conditions. From the earnings her business has generated, she is able to cover 100% of her personal expenses. Mrs. JULIA AMPARO O. has been selling food for 8 years. Her regular clients are policemen. Julia made the decision to do this business because next to her house is a dining room open to everyone. But 8 years ago this business was closed and a lot of people had been going there to eat regularly. This made putting the business there a good idea since she practically had permanent customers. Since that time, Mrs. Julia has been selling food to the policemen. She is married and her husband works in agriculture. Their four at-home daughters also work to prepare the meals. Mrs. YOLANDA MARIBEL M. has been selling bread and candy for 4 years. Yolanda bakes twice a week and sells her candy on Sundays. She’s sells the candy at the soccer fields. She is a mother of 3 children who depend on her 100%. Her husband works in the fields. With the earnings generated by her business, she has been able to support her husband in covering certain family expenses. All these families need the loans to succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Jo Longnecker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of creams, deorderants, disinfectants, eye shadows, lotions, lipstick, shines, powders, corn, beans, chicken, beef and pork, sausages, lard, eggs,  rice, butter, cheese, sugar, spaghetti, pastas, flour, salsas, soda.

loans.name: Nuon

texts.en:
V., a 54-year-old woman, lives in the "Kingdom of Wonder" capital, Phnom Penh. She has been a silk weaver for 29 years – a skill she learned from her grandmother. She sells her finished product to a middleman, who then takes it to re-sell at the local market and supermarket. V. has also been hired by the villagers to spin silk, from which she earns extra income.

V. has been married for years and has eight children: five of them are single, and the others are married and have already started new homes. Most of her children assist her with weaving silk. Her husband has been farming for years. V. is requesting a loan of US $500 to purchase more silk materials to continue her business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena dreams of a better life for her family. She is willing to do everything just to have her children finish their studies. She is now 49 years old and married to Ruben, a farmer. They have four children: Rodolfo, who has already finished his Criminology course and now works as a Security guard in Manila; and Rowena, a graduating student in college. Magdalena's third child and her youngest child already stopped studying to give way to their sister. Magdalena plans to pursue sending them to college after Rowena finishes her college education.

Magdalena is engaged in managing a general store. From this business, she is generating a net income of PHP100 daily. Because of her low income, Magdalena decided to venture into selling used clothes or second-hand clothing to have additional income to meet the needs of her family. She would like to access a loan amounting to PHP 8,000 from KIVA lenders. She will use the loan to further expand her business to able earn a bigger income. She hopes that her business will be supported by the lenders for it is chance of making her business progressive.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Vevencia

texts.en:
Vevencia Sta. R. is from the village of Liloan-Bonifacio Mis. Occ. She is 54 years old. Vevencia is married and has one adult child. To make a living, Vevencia owns & operates a retail store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Vevencia has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Vevencia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vevencia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Vevencia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units with offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe L. is from the village of Compol, in Catarman Camiguin Province. She is 43 years old. Fe is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Fe owns & operates a business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail business. Her main source of income from the business comes primarily from selling a variety of fish and shrimps in the local market. Fe has been engaged in her business for over 16 years and earns approximately 8760 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Fe joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Fe is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Fe from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support education of children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional supplies of fish and shrimp to sell

loans.name: Hilario

texts.en:
Hilario P. is from the village of Kiburiao, Quezon Bukidnon. He is 43 years old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Hilario owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Hilario has been engaged in his business for over ten years and earns approximately $338 a month from these activities.

In 1997, Hilario joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Hilario has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Hilario is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be his 16th loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding his business

loans.name: Yeun

texts.en: Mrs. Yeun M. lives in Boeng Tranh village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Uong Bros, is a cow middleman. He wants to expand his business since it is doing well, so Mrs. Yeun M. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for her husband's business. Mrs. Yeun M. is a mother of three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while the other two are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is shown on the right in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a cow for her husband's business.

loans.name: Zahidah

texts.en:
Zahida is a hardworking woman who spent her life as a janitor in a public school. She recently reached retirement and has a monthly pension of around 400 USD. Zahida has three adult children: one of them is working as a daily paid worker in Israel while the other two are working in Tulkarem city.

Zahida’s husband is suffering from prostate cancer and he needs treatment in Jordan. The health insurance (government insurance) will cover part of the cost while the other part will be covered from this FATEN loan of 2,000 USD that Zahida has requested.

Zahida appears in the photo at the FATEN office.

loans.use: To pay for her husband's treatment

location.town: Ertah Village, Tulkarem City, West Bank

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is married with 2 children and she is 31 years old. She is a LAPO client. The Lift Above Poverty Organization is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. She is hardworking. She sells sarongs at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She is requesting for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Veronika

texts.es:
Verónika tiene 20 años, es una joven muy trabajadora y alegre, vive en la casa de sus padres Dionicio de 60 y Paulina de 50 años, a quienes desea ayudar con los gastos familiares.
Su stand de ropa está ubicado en el centro de la ciudad de Juliaca, ahí ofrece a sus clientes novedosos y bellos vestidos, los cuales son muy solicitados por las jovencitas, sobre todo para asistir a sus bailes de promoción. Los vestidos que vende los trae desde la ciudad de Tacna (sur del país), es por eso que los modelos son muy novedosos y llamativos; pero también ella misma confecciona algunas prendas que vende directamente en su puesto.
Por otro lado, lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es aconsejar a las jovencitas que vienen a comprar, lleva 3 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que traer los vestidos, ya que el viaje es muy largo y agotador. 
Para más adelante, espera poder tener una tienda más grande donde pueda brindar una mejor atención a sus clientes.

Este es el primer préstamo de Verónica con MFP y a su corta edad ya es muy responsable con su trabajo, por lo que sabe que tiene que pagar sus cuotas a tiempo. En su banco comunal es muy querida por sus compañeras, ya que es la más joven del grupo y es muy alegre. Con los mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará nuevos materiales para elaborar más vestidos y así ofrecer a sus clientes una mayor variedad.
texts.en:
Verónika is 20 years old. She is a hardworking and cheerful young woman who lives at the home of her parents, Dionicio (age 60) and Paulina (age 50). Verónika desires to help them with the family expenses.

She operates a clothing stand in central Juliaca. Verónika offers her customers the latest and most stylish clothing, which are mainly requested by teenage girls especially when they attend their prom. Her clothing is acquired from the city of Tacna (in the southern part of the country), which explains why her clothing is trendy and in fashion. In addition, Verónika manufactures some of the outfits that she sells from her stand. What she enjoys most about her job is giving advice to the young girls who buy from her. She has been in this business for three years and says the hardest part is transporting her inventory because the trip is long and tiring. In the future, she hopes to have a larger shop where she can provide better service to her customers.

This is Verónika’s first loan with MFP. At such a young age, she is very responsible at her job. She knows she has to make her payments on time. Verónika is well-liked by the other members of her Communal Bank for her cheerful disposition and because she is the youngest member of the group. With her loan of 1000 soles, she plans to buy material for producing more dresses to sell so that she can offer her customers a wider variety.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase material for making dresses

loans.name: Diego

texts.en: 39-year-old Diego T. is a fisherman and at the same time a fish vendor in Talibon Bohol. He said that his only dream is to be able to fulfill his obligation in sending his children to school. He wants them to be professionals someday so that they will be able to find good employment when they are older. He is seeks a loan of 15,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the proceeds of this loan to buy more fish to resell, and fishing supplies.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish to resell at market, and fishing supplies.

loans.name: Margaret Wambui

texts.en:
Margaret is 39 years-old and unmarried. She has two children. aged 10 years and 19 years, respectively. She lives in Muthiga where she also has her retail shop. She has been selling different items in her shop for the last four years and now has stable and reliable customers.

She was introduced to Kiva partner KADET by a friend and this will be her first time to seek a loan. She has no previous credit history and she plans to use the loan amount to restock her retail shop with items such as detergent, flour, tea leaves, tissue paper, etc.

Margaret intends to enlarge her shop by becoming a wholesaler supplying other retailers within the surrounding areas of Muthiga. This will enable her to eventually improve her living standard and the lives of her children.

loans.use: To increase her store stock.

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanna C. (shown in the photo), age 44, and her husband, Mr. Penh Uk, live in a small village across the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1995 and have one son who attends school. 

Vanna has been a silk weaver for fifteen years. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who then takes them to sell in the market in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a carpenter for twenty years. Vanna is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase silk material for her weaving business, and she will use part of her loan to buy wooden materials for her husband’s carpentry business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for weaving.

loans.name: Jonalyn

texts.en:
Jonalyn C. is from the village of P-Bularan, Miputak, Dipolog City. She is 31 years old, married, and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Jonalyn owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Jonalyn has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Jonalyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jonalyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to expand shelter for the borrower's livestock. Jonalyn is requesting a new loan of 14,500 PHP, which will be used to purchase construction materials for house repair. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Jonalyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase construction materials for house repair.

loans.name: Shiden's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Shiden S. is from Kampong Svay village in Kandal province. She is 60 years old and is the village bank president of her group, which consists of twenty-four members, who are the subject of this loan offered by AMK. Each member of this village loan will use it to purchase supplies, equipment and other items to support their different purposes.

Mrs. Shiden S. is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice. Aside from farming, she is also a pig breeder who is able to make a small income to support her family.

Since, Mrs. Shiden S.’s pig business is going well she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets to enlarge her business.

Mrs. Shiden S. is a widow with six childR., four of whom are seamstresses in the garment factory and the other two stay at home and also support their mother’s business.

loans.use: To buy more piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel L. is from the village of Olango. He is 58 years old, married, and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Samuel plants and harvests rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over 26 years and earns approximately $790 per harvest.

In 2008, Samuel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Samuel is requesting a new loan of 21,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase fertilizers. This will be his 5th loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Mama

texts.fr: Madame Mama D. est mère de 2 jumeaux âgés de 3 ans et d’un petit enfant d’un an. Elle est vendeuse de divers éléments depuis 12 ans.  Commençant dans le métier de l’aviculture, Madame Mama D. se voit complètement virer dans le commerce de tissus, draps, poulets et de moutons. Elle compte avec ce prêt acheter des draps à Touba (ville religieuse située à 180 Kms de Dakar) et des moutons  à Kaolack sa ville d’origine. Cependant, elle va élever ces moutons pour préparer une opération Tabaski (fête du sacrifice qui va se fêter en Novembre prochain). Ainsi, ce crédit va lui permettre de développer et renforcer son commerce.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mama D. is mother to three-year old twins and a one-year old baby. She has been selling a variety of items for the past 12 years. Having started her working life with poultry-farming, Mrs. Dialla completely changed direction by taking up the sale of fabrics, sheets, chickens and sheep. She is planning on using this loan to buy sheets in Touba (a religious town which lies 180 kilometers from Dakar) and sheep in Kaolack, the town where she comes from. She will raise the sheep in order to prepare for an "opération" (a fair initiated by the government where sheep will be sold directly to consumers) held at Tabaski (a sacrificial festival which will be celebrated next November). This loan will allow her thus to develop and strengthen her business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To get fresh supplies of goods

loans.name: Sorbeh 1A Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are the three members of the Sorbeh IA Group. They are small-scale businesspeople based in Makump Bana village, located about five miles from Makeni city in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of SLL 1,200,000 each to enable them to further expand their businesses. Consequently, they will make more profit and improve on their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Musa S. B. (pictured on the left). He was born in Makump Bana village and is age 36. He is married with five children. His wife is a businesswoman and his children are attending primary schools.

For more than seven years now, Musa has been selling dishes, cottons and T-Shirts. With his share of this loan, he will buy more dishes, cottons and T-Shirts to add to his inventory.

loans.use: To buy more dishes, cottons and T-Shirts to sell

loans.name: Hadabia Binaka

texts.fr:
Agée de 37 ans, cette femme est mariée avec 05 enfants. Elle est propriétaire d’une boutique renommé appelé « SOURCE DE VIE ». Elle y vend des produits d'alimentation générale et des boissons.
L’objet du crédit est l’achat de produits d'alimentation générale et de boissons pour répondre avec satisfaction à la demande des clients en forte augmentation.
Elle espère avec l’évolution probable de son activité due à ce crédit, augmenter et conforter son autonomie financière.
texts.en:
This woman, 37, is married with five children. She owns a well-known shop called « SOURCE DE VIE » (source of life). She sells various foodstuffs and drinks. The goal of her loan is to buy more foodstuffs and drinks so as to meet the needs of her quickly growing clientele. With the expected growth of her business due to this loan, she hopes to bolster her economic autonomy.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of foodstuffs

loans.name: Adiba Siddique's Group

texts.en:
Adiba siddique has been living in Borewala, city of shrines, in Pakistan for the last 16 years with her husband and four children, who are all getting their education. Her husband is a motor mechanic, while Adiba sews clothes for her neighborhood clients in order to support her husband financially. Adiba’s husband runs a motor workshop in the market where he can repair every kind of vehicle. He started learning this art at a young age, and now he is an expert at it.
 
Adiba has applied for a loan from Asasah to invest the loan amount in her husband’s workshop. The amount will help him buy new repair tools for his workshop. She is hopeful that the investment in her husband’s business will make it more profitable.

loans.use: To purchase repair tools for her husband's motor workshop

loans.name: Banah's Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi 1 est un regroupement composé de huit femmes toutes mariées dans des grandes familles traditionnelles, ayant un âge moyen de 56 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes le village de N’Gama dans la commune rurale de N’Gara dans la 4ème région administrative du Mali, qu’est Ségou. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage et cultivent l’arachide, le mil et le riz.
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs champs de riz pendant l’hivernage, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt de campagne. 
Madame Bassouma D.  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 3 sacs de complexe céréale et recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour, de repiquage  et de sarclage dans son champ de riz. 
Il est à noter que dans ce village N’Gama, les activités de labour et de sarclage des champs sont l’œuvre des hommes alors que le repiquage et le désherbage du riz sont effectués par les associations de femmes du village. 
Bassouma D. se ravitaille en engrais à la foire de Konodimini auprès des grossistes. Avec une superficie de 2 hectares, elle compte réaliser  20 sacs de riz.  
Une partie de la récolte est auto consommée tandis que le reste est vendu. 
Le bénéfice obtenu est utilisé pour prendre en charge les petits besoins du foyer.
texts.en:
Benkadi 1 is a group of eight women who are all married and live in traditional households; they are around 56 years old and have four children each. They all live in N'Gama village in Segou, the fourth largest administrative building in Mali, and met each other through family and friends; they cultivate peanuts, millet and rice. In order to enlarge their rice fields they are seeking a second loan from Soro Yiriwaso. Madame Bassouma D. aims to use her loan both to purchase three bags of complex cereals and to hire some staff in order to cultivate, pick and hoe the rice fields. In N'Gama village, labour and picking the fields is generally men's work, whereas weeding the rice is done by women's associations in the village. Bassouma D. sources her fertiliser from wholesalers at the Konodimini market. She aims to utilise her 2 hectar land in order to generate 20 bags of rice. Part of the harvest is consumed by those involved in its production, and the rest is sold. The profits generated are used to meet family needs.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fertiliser and employ labour

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba E. is a fish monger from Abura. She has received a junior high school education. She is married and living with her five dependants. Her husband is a farmer. She helps her husband by taking care of the family with the profit she makes from her trade. Her loan will be used to buy more fish to smoke for distribution. She hopes to save the profits from her business to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: To buy more fish to smoke for distribution

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna M. is from the village of Northern Pob. Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 46 years old. Myrna is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Myrna owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste, powdered soap, rice, canned goods, and coffee, in the local community. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Myrna joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Myrna from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy C. is from the town of Banga. She is 37 years old. Juvy is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Juvy owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Juvy has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

Juvy joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juvy has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Juvy is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. This will be the second loan taken out by Juvy from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Sabanalamarino Unidos 1 Group

texts.en:
Barbara is the coordinator of her group, Sabanalamarino Unidos 1 (Sabanalamarino Together). "Sabanalamarino" is the name people receive when they were born in Sabana D. la Mar, a fishing village. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long term partner and three children. She says that her most difficult challenge is to educate her children. In the meantime, she enjoys being with her family at home.

Barbara is excited to be taking out her 7th loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans and grown her business. She has had her business for over five years, starting when she asked her father for the opportunity to sell seafood, buying it from him and other friends. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by buying some pounds of fish and different kinds of seafood. She will use the profits to invest in the education of her children and to have a bigger home.

This Esperanza associate began with us because she liked how the loans work, and she needed to invest in her business. Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti). Her group is located in the rural area around the coast called Sabana D. la Mar, a fishing village, surrounding Hato Mayor, an agricultural area. This area, like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, suffers from unreliable electricity and running water (none of which is potable).

loans.use: to buy fish and sea food

loans.name: Juanita's Group

texts.en:
Juanita C., from the village of Mangandingay Cabarroguis, Quirino, is the 45-year-old group leader of a three-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Juanita, who is married and has two school-aged children, owns and operates a direct-selling business offering cosmetics and apparel products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over three years, she earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Juanita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Jaratu

texts.en: Jaratu E. is a petty trader. She is married and has three kids. Her husband is a plumber. Jaratu sells dried maize at Nyinasi near Abura. She buys the maize from the farmer and then dries it before she sells to her customers. She will use the loan she will take to buy more of the maize she dries to sell. Jaratu will then use the profit she gets from the business to further her children’s education and also help her husband to cater for her family.

loans.use: buy more maize she dries for resale

loans.name: Pamella

texts.en:
Pamella N. lives in the Nalukolongo neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has five children, one of whom is in school. She also takes care of additional family members (her sister). Pamella has a retail shop. She has been in this business for 2 years and works 6 days a week. She has requested a loan of 700,000/ Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO which she will use to buy bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and cooking oil. She also generates additional income through commercial farming and charcoal selling. The main business challenges for Pamella include seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to expand to a big supermarket. 

Pamella lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food and rent.

loans.use: To buy stock

loans.name: Pom's Group

texts.en:
Four people form this group loan. They are living in Krabau village in Kandal province. This group selected Mrs. Pom C., a 28-year-old married woman, as the group leader. Each member of the group will use their portion of the loan to support their different purpose. 

Mrs. Pom C. earns her living by vegetable selling. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. So she would like to ask for a loan to buy more vegetable to enlarge her business activities. Her husband, Mr. Preap BunthoE., 40, works as a body guard. With both their  businesses, they are able to earn a good income to support their family. This couple has a child who is 2 years old.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to enlarge her business activities.

loans.name: Maxima

texts.en:
Maxima is a 42-year-old mother of three children whose futures she and her husband work hard to ensure. Maxima is thankful to ASHI for the loans it has provided since 1999 that have enabled her fishing operation to grow through the purchase of a motor boat, fishing net and other business-related materials. She is now requesting a new loan to purchase additional fishing nets and fish cages (traps) and hopes to increase the amount of fish she can sell in the future through hard work and the continuing assistance of Kiva Partner ASHI.

Maxima's membership in ASHI gave her the chance to have her own business. Because of her excellent credit performance throughout her membership in ASHI, from an initial loan of Php5,000 she can now avail Php40,000.00 and could even reach the peak amount available in the future. Therefore, Maxima looks forward to continued business growth through both the loans and the help of her supportive husband, Mamerto, who is her business partner.

When she reaches the highest loan amount that ASHI can offer, she plans to rent a space in the market where she can sell their fish. With the opportunity provided by her membership in ASHI, Maxima can help send their three children to school until they complete college degrees. The couple believes that when they pass away, they will at least have made their business successful and their children can have a business. Maxima’s hard work and patience are her foundation in working to achieve a better life for them.

Maxima is very happy to be a Kiva borrower and says thank you for offering financial support of her business endeavor.

loans.use: To purchase additional fishing nets and fish cages (traps)

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites A. is from the village of Salay, Misamis Oriental. She is 42 years old. Marites is married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, Marites owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods & junk food in the local community. Marites has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marites joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. Marites is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products like beverages & breads. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Marites from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products like beverages & breads

loans.name: Maritza Augusta

texts.es:
La Señorita Maritza G. es socia de banco comunal Prosperidad, vive en el centro de la ciudad de C., esta ciudad es reconocida por su belleza arquitectónica, su gente mantiene su cultura y tradiciones la misma que es muy amable y cordial.

La Señorita. Maritza tiene 37 años de edad, es soltera y vive independiente en un departamento que es de su propiedad, se dedica a laborar como auxiliar contable, actividad que desempeña hace 17 años, trabaja de lunes a viernes desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 7 de la noche. En sus tiempos libres también se dedica a la venta de ropa por catalogo actividad que realiza hace 3 años.

Es su primer crédito que realiza en el banco comunal y fue invitada por su hermana quien es socia activa del banco, el dinero de su crédito lo va a invertir en ropa para surtir más su mercadería. Su meta es tener su propio local para vender su mercadería.
texts.en:
Maritza G. is a member of the community bank Prosperidad [Prosperity] and lives in the center of the city of C., a city known for its beautiful architecture.  People maintain their culture and traditions and they are very kind and friendly.

Maritza is 37 years old, single, and lives independently in an apartment that she owns.  She has worked as a junior accountant for 17 years.  She works from Monday to Friday from 8:00am until 7:00pm.  In her free time, she sells clothing from catalogs.  She has done this for three years.

This is her first loan with the community bank.  Her sister, who is an active member of the community bank, invited her to join.  She will use the loan to purchase more merchandise.  Her goal is to have her own store to sell clothing.

loans.use: Purchase clothes

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy blouses, jeans skirts, and underclothes to sell to her customers

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is a married woman who lives in Bantayan, Cebu. She earns her living by operating one business: a general store  .Her husband, Juanito, who is 62 years-old, works as a Driver to earn his living.  They have five children who are 25 to 32 years old. Three of their children have their own families.

Teresita joined Kiva partner NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Teresita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 5,000,  uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 16th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500, and she plans to buy stock for her general store so that she can continue to save up for future improvement of her business.

Teresita is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the poverty alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.
