texts.es:
El Sr Pedro M. vive en la ciudad de San Roque Gonzalez, a unos 15 Km de Carapeguá; es un señor muy trabajador,  desde muy joven se dedicó a  ayudar a sus padres  ya que los mismos no podían  sustentar los gastos de la casa. 
Ya adulto el Sr. Pedro decidió comenzar un negocio cual es la venta de ropas y calzados a crédito, al tener más pedidos de mercaderías se vio con la necesidad de recurrir a nuestra institución para solicitar préstamo de manera a que pueda aumentar su capital. 
Solicitó el préstamo para la compra de sábanas, hamacas, calzados ya que ha recibido muchos pedidos de estas mercaderías se parte de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Pedro M. lives in the city of San Roque Gonzalez, 15 km from Carapegúa. He is a hard-worker and has worked since very young to support his parents who could not afford the household costs. As an adult, Pedro decided to begin a business in the sales of clothing and shoes on credit. Upon receiving a greater number of orders than merchandise, he saw the need to come to our institution to request a loan to increase his working capital.

He has requested this loan to purchase curtains, hammocks and shoes, since he has received many orders for this merchandise from his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase bed covers, curtains, hammocks and shoes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy tools and renovate garage

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita L. is from the village of Lupagan Clarin Misamis Occidental. She is 68 years old. Teresita is widowed and has 8 adult children. To make a living, Teresita owns and operates a store selling products like milo (malted milk), coffee, eggs,candies, biscuits,sugar and salt. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Teresita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from GDMPC. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 13th loan taken out by Teresita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Donathile

texts.en:
Donathile is 35 years old, married with a three-year-old child and she takes care of three dependents, ages 3, 6 and 8 years old.  Donathile struggles by selling a variety of goods in her shop as her photo indicates.  Those goods include cosmetic goods and drinks.  She has been in this business for about three years and the hours of her business are from 6 am until late in the evening.

Donathile realized which items the people from her business area are interested in buying so she wants to put her energy into selling those drinks which are more profitable.  In addition, she wants also to start wholesaling to the retailers.  In doing so, Donathile will hopefully earn more profit, which in turn will allow her to build a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics and drinks.

loans.name: Nanziga Kwagalana Group Of  Mpigi

texts.en:
It goes without saying that Samali K. is a 38-year-old self-assured and high-spirited mother of four.  She has a well-rounded experience of ten years in pig husbandry and agricultural produce sales.

In Nanzoga, Mpigi, Samali has established a business niche for herself on the basis of her down-the-line hard-work spirit.  She has had financial difficulties in her piggery business before but, given her beaten-track experience, she has managed to nip them in the bud earlier.

In the same breath, what has also made Samali’s produce sales business successful is the fact that she has always owed it to herself to provide the best possible quality produce for her clients.  At present, she makes monthly profits to the tune of 200,000 shillings. With these combined businesses, she has consolidated her profits and, as a result, all her children are in school.

With this loan, Samali wants to herald a new chapter in her business by buying more surplus crops like maize and cabbages. She also wants to ring substantial changes in her pig-husbandry business, which means buying more pigs that she will be able to sell to her increasing client base.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs and crops like maize, cabbages and peas

loans.name: Mojisola

texts.en:
Mojisola sells and supplies foodstuffs like bags of rice, beans and gallons of groundnut (peanut) oil. She travels outside Lagos to buy her goods. She has been in the business for the past seven years

Mojisola is 38 years old and she has one child. She lives in Lagos with her husband, who is a Navy officer.

Mojisola hopes for the loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs like rice, beans and groundnut oil to sell. This she said will reduce her traveling expenses, attract a greater discount and earn more profits.

Mojisola says thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs like rice, beans and groundnut oil to sell

loans.name: Prosscovia

texts.en: Prosscovia is married with two children who go to school.  She also takes care of her old mother. She resides in and owns a three-room house. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Prosscovia owns a stall in Kalerwe market selling second hand clothes. She sells to all categories of people. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes.  Prosscovia has been in this business for seven years. She works seven days a week. Prosscovia buys these clothes from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala city and uses public transport to and from shopping. Prosscovia goes shopping every Monday.  She incurs transport costs to and from shopping.  Her business challenges include transportation and defaulters. She aspires to go directly to Mombasa for clothes.  She joined MCDT because she wanted to get additional capital for her business. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Last summer, Elizabeth came to ACCION USA for her second loan, which provided her with $6,000 to refurbish part of her beauty salon in Long Island City. She used the money to install a new beauty station and buy another hairdryer chair.

When borrowers pay down 40% of their loans with ACCION USA, they are eligible to refinance for more funds. In April, when Elizabeth had paid down about 60% of her loan, she came to us to refinance in order to make further improvements to her salon. 

With her loan, Elizabeth will refurbish the tile flooring in her salon and to buy additional dryers. Elizabeth will be able to continue strengthening her credit and making her salon more welcoming and professional-looking to customers. Ultimately, she hopes this renovation of her business space leads to a more profitable business to support her and her husband and children.


 About U.S. Microfinance and ACCION USA:
Have you ever thought about how the cute new café on your corner or the salon you frequent every month got the financial resources to start their business? Chances are, they drummed up support from their friends and family, dipped into their personal savings, used a high-interest credit card, or all of the above. An estimated ten million small businesses in the U.S. face difficulty obtaining loans from traditional banks, even prior to the current “credit crisis”. Microfinance institutions, like ACCION USA, support these “unbanked” small businesses by giving them access to fairly-priced capital and business education.

Small businesses also help stabilize low- to moderate-income neighborhoods and rebuild our economy through income growth and job creation. Self-employment provides workers with a way to increase their incomes, support their families, and strengthen their communities. As unemployment rises in the U.S., more and more people are turning to self-employment and start-up enterprises as a way to take control of their economic futures and provide employment opportunities in their communities. The need for support of small businesses in the U.S. is great, and it is one that ACCION USA has been striving to meet since 1991.

loans.use: To install a new tile flooring and additional hairdryers

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en:
Ofelia F. is from the town of Santo Niño. She is 43 years old, married to Reynaldo, and has seven school-aged children. She is involved in farming. She owns two hectares of land where she and her husband plant and harvest rice crops. They also help each other sell their harvest at the market. She also raises hogs and hopes to acquire additional piglets. 

Ofelia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure, and to buy feed for the pigs. This will be her 8th loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and feeds for the pigs

loans.name: Galib

texts.ru:
Galib Azizovu 47 let. On jivet v Baku qorode. On jenat i imeyet 2 detey dochek odna iz kotoroy 17 let i ona v etom qodu postupayet v universitet a druqaya yey 15 let i ona idet na muziku zanimayetsya skripkoy. On v etom biznese uje 7 let. 

Teper Galib nujdayetysa v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit nujniye zapchasti dlya mashini . Posledniy raz on povez kliyenta v derevnu i tam doroqi bili ploximi posle etoqo mashina u neqo isportilas. teper on xotel bi za schet etoqo kredita ispravit mashinu i s udobstvom vozit ludiy v nujniye punkti.
texts.en:
Galib A. is 47 years old. He lives in Baku. He is married and has two children. One daughter is seventeen years old and is entering the university this year. The other is fifteen and she studies the violin. He has been doing this business for seven years. Galib now needs 2000 AZN to pay for necessary repairs for his car. The last time he took a client to the countryside the roads were bad, and after that his car was ruined. Now, he would like to take out a loan to fix his car so he can comfortably transport people to where they need to go.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy spare parts for his car

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi A. sells rice and tinned tomatoes in Abura. Esi has received a senior high school education. She is married to a driver and has one child. She responsibly supports her husband in providing the basic needs of her family. Her loan will be added to her business income to buy more of her goods to sell. She wishes to reinvest her new profits into her business.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Soun

texts.en:
Soun A. is 47 years-old, married and devoted to her four children.  Two are already married and have their own homes, while the other two are single. She was married but divorced her husband when her children where young. 

As a means of income, Soun A. owns a small business selling fresh fish to villagers. Soun A. also owns a plot of farmland that was inherited from her grandparents and where she plans to plant crops for extra income. At present, Soun A. doesn't have the capital to make that possible so she would like a  loA. in order to grow green beans.

loans.use: To grow green beans.

loans.name: Victoria Womens Group A-Lugazi

texts.en: 30 year old K. Mary runs a general merchandise retail shop in Kiyindi-Lugazi. She took the reins 3 years ago after her husband asked her to start her own income generating project to help him provide for the family. She and her husband have 3 children. In a month, Mary who is a hard worker, as evidenced by all the effort she's put into her shop, makes 224,000 Ugandan shillings. With this loan she wants to buy more retail items for her shop. She wants to buy more bags of sugar, rice, salt, plastics, maize flour, beans and saucepans.

loans.use: expanding store inventory

loans.name: Prosperidad Leal Group

texts.es: La Sra. Rosa Gladys tiene 50 años de edad es Secretaria del Grupo “Prosperidad Leal”, vive en Chaclacayo, es casada y tiene dos hijos, vendía jugos y ensaladas, de esto ya hace 5 años, lleva 1 año trabajando con Edaprospo, Ella esta contenta con su fuente de soda llamado “SIWASE”, no obstante últimamente ha implementado un mostrador para la venta de pasteles y dulces. Junto a sus vecinas de la zona, amigas y señoras responsables se han unido para alcanzar con la ayuda de Edaprospo sus metas y esperan mejorar su forma de vida y en particular la señora Gladys espera poder poner otro local, el prestamo que ha recibido estara destinado para la compra de insumos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Rosa Gladys is 50 years old and lives in Chaclacayo, she is married and has two children. She has been selling juices and salads for the last 5 years and for the past year she has been Secretary of the “Prosperidad Leal” (Loyal Prosperity) Group which has been working with Edaprospo for one year, She is happy with her source of soda called “SIWASE” and recently she has installed a counter for selling cakes and sweets. Together with her neighbors in the area, friends and responsible ladies they have got together to achieve, with the help of Edaprospo, their goals and they hope to improve their way of life and, in particular Gladys hopes to be able to set up another stall.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: PURCHASE PRODUCTS AND RAW MATERIALS

loans.name: Nsaggu Akugoba Women's Group-Mpigi

texts.en: Thirty-nine year old David K., who belongs to Nsaggu Akugoba Women’s group-Mpigi, has been in general merchandise retailing for the last 7 years. Self-motivation is what made him an upstart in this business, he is so endeared on the basis that he and his family have met financial from the business. David values his hard work and it’s the sole reason he says he has achieved this longevity. David is happily married with 4 kids. In a week, his business generates him shillings 100,000, and with this loan he is looking at purchasing more bags of sugar, salt,  beans, rice, bread, and plastics for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of sugar, salt, beans, rice, etc.

loans.name: El Sol Sale Para Todos 4 & 6 Group

texts.es:
Flor es una D. los miembros del grupo El Sol Sale para Todos 4 y 6, ellos son microempresarios dedicados a las ventas D. ropa, productos naturales, zapatos, educacion, ventas D. comida, etc; en la ciudad D. Hato Mayo una D. las ciudades mas rurales del pais, cuya economia depenD. D. la agricultura. Está asociada D. Esperanza es madre D. cinco hijos, casada, e inicio su negocio con el primer prestamo recibido D. Esperanza y actualmente llega 6 años y esta recibiendo su septimo prestamo, en cada uno ha realizado sus pagos satisfactoriamente y ha realizado buenas inversiones. Ella actualmente esta operando un pica pollo (pequeño restaurante D. pollos fritos)

Flor está planificando invertir su nuevo préstamo en la compra D. Pollo, platanos, papas, harina, refrescos, etc. Ella va a utilizar sus ganancias para construir el techo D. su casa en concreto pagar sus gastos publicos e ir ahorrando con la finalidad D. poder terminar D. construir su vivienda. Su actividad favorita es ir a la iglesia y su reto primordial es cuidar a sus nietos, los cuales viven con ella
texts.en:
Flor is a member of the “El Sol Sale Para Todos 4 y 6” (The Sun Rises for Everyone 4 & 6).  They are micro businesspeople in clothing sales, sales of natural products, shoes, teachers, food sales, etc. in the city of Hato Mayo, one of the most rural cities in the country whose economy depends on agriculture.

This associate of Esperanza is a mother of five children.  She’s married and started her business with the first loan she got from Esperanza.  She is now in her sixth year and receiving her 7th loan.  Each previous loan has been repaid satisfactorily and she has maD. good investments.

She is currently operating a “pica pollo” (small fried chicken restaurant).  She is planning to use the new loan to buy chicken, bananas, potatoes, flour, refreshments, etc.

She will use profits to install a concrete roof on her house, to pay public utilities and to save some in order to finish building her house.

Her favorite pastime is going to church and her primary challenge is caring for her grandchildren who live with her.

loans.use: For chicken, bananas, potatoes, flour, beverages, etc.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane P. is from the town of Banga. She is 40 years old. Jane is married and has a 21-year-old child. She raises pigs and farms for a living. The pigs she grows are for fattening and sale. She also helps her husband plant and harvest rice crops. Jane also started a sari-sari store to help provide their daily needs. She hopes for all her ventures to succeed.

Jane joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jane has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. 

Jane is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase feeds, farm supplies and additional merchandise to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase feeds, farm supplies and additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Phylis

texts.en:
Phylis is a single woman with one child who attend school. She rents a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

She has operated her M-pesa (Mobile money transfer) business for four months. Her potential customers are passersby and town dwellers. She faces a major challenge of theft in her place of operation. Phylis hopes to open two more branches of mobile money transfer services in the future. 

She decided to join Yehu to get loans to modify her business. With the KES 40,000 she wants to purchase a money float for mobile transfer services and airtime cards for resale.

loans.use: To purchase a money float for mobile money transfers and airtime cards for resale.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam D. is from the village of Pokr Sepasar in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She has been a very hard-working, sincere farmer for the past forty years.  Mariam is a widow with five children. She has four daughters (thirty-three, thirty-one, thirty, and twenty-two years old).  Mariam’s son is twenty years old.  

Microfinance has helped Mariam grow her cattle breeding business.  She is looking for a loan to purchase additional calves and increase her income by up to forty percent.  She expects to use some of the proceeds of her investment to help pay for her son’s wedding.  She enjoys living in Pokr Sepasar surrounded by her family and friends.

loans.use: purchase calves

loans.name: Meas' Group

texts.en:
Twelve people make up this village bank loan. They are living in Srae Kouk village in Kandal province. This village bank loan selected Mrs. Meas M., who is 48 years old, as the village bank president. Each member will use their portion of the loan to support their different purposes. 

Mrs. Meas M. is a farmer who owns a one-hectare rice field to cultivate rice for a living. Now her rice field is ready to harvest, but she doesn’t have enough money to support it, so she decided to ask for a loan to hire farm laborers to harvest her rice field. Her husband, Mr. Chab Chhieng, 47 years old, works as a car driver and also helps in his wife's farming. 

This couple has five children, two of whom are car mechanics and three are students. who also support their parents' farming.

loans.use: To hire farm laborers to harvest her rice field.

loans.name: Meloma Group

texts.es:
El siguiente grupo que presento se llama "Meloma" lo integran 8 mujeres muy trabajadoras de la comunidad de San Francisco La Loma, está comunidad pertenece al municipio de San José del Rincon, México. San Francisco La Loma alberga familias cuya actividad se enfoca a la agricultura y ganaderia, despues encontramos el comercio, en lo general son tiendas de abarrotes o gente que sale a distintas plazas para ofrecer productos tales como plastico, cinturones o ropa.

El grupo "Meloma" no es la excepción por que sus 8 integrantes son amas de casa pero con un negocio o una actividad extra. Las mujeres que las integran son las siguientes:
1.-Francisca C. M., tiene 45 años de edad y su actividad es el comercio vendiendo los dias de plaza ropa para la familia
2.-Maria Guadalupe M. M.,  tiene 41 años de edad, es ama de casa, se dedica a criar pollos para  vender
3.-Maria Guadalupe R. R., tiene 73 años de edad, se dedica al hogar y a criar animales, en este caso becerros.
4.- Jovita M. S., tiene 50 años de edad, ama de casa y se dedica a atender una tienda de abarrotes
5.-Maria del Carmén T. R., tiene 47 años, se dedica  al hogar, y en su casa tiene una tienda de abarrotes.
6.-Isidra T. D., tiene 44 años, es ama de casa y su negocio es la cria de pollos para vender
7.-Maria Luisa R. R., tiene 26 años, es la más joven del grupo, ama de casa, y tambíen sale a vender los dias de plaza ropa para la familia
8.-Margarita C. M., tiene 47 años de edad, es la presidenta del grupo, ama de casa y se dedica a criar animales, por lo regular los animales que cria son borregos y pollos.

Todo el grupo se conocen desde que eran pequeños, se decidieron llamar "MELOMA" porqué es el como un apodo a la comunidad, San Francisco de la loma es "MELOMA".

Tambien cabe mencionar que es una comunidad "Mazahua", la mayor parte de la población adulta hablan este dialecto, sin embargo los niños lo han dejado de hacer, por eso en las escuelas primarias lo estan tratando de esnseñar para que los niños lo aprendan y este idioma no se pierda, es una materia más que los niños llevan en clase. 

Doña Margarita que de cariño la llaman doña Mago, es una mujer como mencionabamos Mazahua, es casada y en total tuvo 11 hijos, de casada cumplio 33 años, tiene casa propia y vive con su señor esposo, de los 11 hijos que tuvo 2 fallecieron y solo le quedan 9 hijos, 4 son mujeres y 5 hombres.

Hay dos personas que dependen de doña Mago, un hijo de 11 años que estudia el 5 año de primaria y una nieta de 4 años, solo estas dos persona dependen de doña Mago. El esposo de doña Mago es agricultor, no tiene un trabajo fijo, pero también cuando se puede se va a trabajar de albañil para tener más dinero.

Tambíen cabe mencionar que doña Mago es una mujer lider en su comunidad, hay gente que la sigue y la apoya en las desiciones que toma.

La mayor parte de la gente de la comunidad es gente sencilla y es gente humilde, como tambien es gente que cumple y que apoya se así se requiera.
texts.en:
This group is named "Meloma". It is made up of 8 very hard working women who live in the community of San Francisco La Loma. This community belongs to the municipality of San Jose del Rincon in Mexico. San Francisco La Loma's population consists of families who are agriculturists and farmers. There are also merchants who have general stores or those who travel to the various plazas to sell their products, such as plastics, belts, and clothing.

The group "Meloma" is not different from other group because the 8 members are house wives who have a business on the side. The women of the group are the following: 

1.-Francisca C. M.: she is 45 years old and she is a merchant who sells clothing for the entire family in the plazas.
2.-Maria Guadalupe M. M.: she is 41 years old, she is a house wife, and she raises chickens which she later sells. 
3.-Maria Guadalupe R. R.: she is 73 years old and she raises livestock. Currently she raises pigs.
4. - Jovita M. S.: she is 50 years old and she has a convenience store.
5.-Maria del Carmen T. R.: She is 47 years old and she has a convenience store.
6.-Isidra T. D.: She is 44 years old and she raises chickens which she later sells.
7.-Maria Luisa R. R.: she is 26 years old, the youngest in the group, had she also goes out to the plazas to sell clothing
8.-Margarita C. M.: she is 47 years old and she is the leader of the group. She raises livestock. Usually she raises sheep and chickens.

The members of the group know each other since they were children. They decided on the name "Meloma" because it is the nickname of the community: San Francisco de la Loma is "Meloma".

It should also be mentioned that the community is Mazahua, meaning that the majority of the adult population speak this dialect. But the kids have stopped learning the language, which is why the primary schools are trying to bring back the language so that it will not be lost. Language class is one of the courses kids take in school.

Margarita, who they affectionately cal Mago, is a Mazahua. She is married and she has 11 children. She has been married for 33 years. She lives in her own home and she lives together with her husband. Of the 11 children, 2 passed away so she only has 9 left; four are girls and 5 are boys. 

There are two that depend on Mago. Her 11-year old son is in grade 5 and she has a 4-year old granddaughter. They are her two last dependents. Mago's husband is an agriculturist. He doesn't have a steady job but whenever a construction job becomes available he takes it to have more money. 

It should also be mentioned that Mago is a leader in her community. There are people that follow her and support her in the decisions that she takes. 

For the most part the population is made up of simple and humble individuals with integrity and they support each other as needed.

loans.use: To purchase sheep and chickens to raise.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more consignments of medicine

loans.name: Saom

texts.en: Sewing clothes is the main part of 28-year-old Saom C.’s daily duty in the garment industry. Saom C. has been at her job since 2009 and earns a formal salary. She currently lives in a small house with her parents in Kompong Chhnang Province. This rice harvesting season Saom C. is requesting a loan in order to purchase sacks of rice to store. She will sell them when the rice is commanding the highest price.

loans.use: To purchase rice while price are low for future sales

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian N. is 28 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala central region of Uganda. She is married and has one child, who is not currently in school. Lilian has a business selling bananas, which she has run for five years.
To help expand her business, Lilian has requested a loan of 1,500,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more bananas for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Lilian hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself. In the future, she hopes to own another food stall.

loans.use: To purchase more bananas for resale

loans.name: Solina

texts.en:
Solina T. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 42 years old. Solina is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Solina owns and operates a business selling used clothing to local community members. Solina has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately PHP 4,000 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Solina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Solina has successfully repaid a previous loan of PHP 5,000 from PMPC. That loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. 

Solina is requesting a new loan of PHP 7,000, which will be used to purchase bundles of used clothing to sell. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Solina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase used clothing to resell

loans.name: María Karina

texts.es:
EL Banco Comunal Soraya  se reúne cada quince días en el Cantón Montecristi, conocido por su rica cultura pre colonial y por su artesanía, que es reconocida a nivel nacional e internacional. Lugar de los famosos sombreros de paja toquilla.

Aquí conocimos a María, tiene 27 años de edad y está  soltera. Ella alquila un departamento junto con su prima, estudia un diplomado en la ULEAN y además trabaja en un colegio particular. Lleva en el Banco Comunal ya cuatro ciclos y le gusta porque a través de estos créditos ella puede en cierta parte financiar su negocio y así poder salir adelante.

Se dedica a la venta productos Yanbal (artículos de belleza, cosméticos perfumería y accesorios para damas). Trabaja todos los días desde las 8h30 hasta las 13h00 en su colegio y en las tardes recorre la ciudad para enseñar sus productos, entregar y realizar los cobros ya que deja a crédito y cobra semanalmente, lleva siete años que se dedica a esta actividad y lo que más vende son los cosméticos y los perfumes.
 
Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar perfumes, bisutería, cosméticos, cremas y otros productos. Sus sueños son  terminar sus estudios.
texts.en:
The Soraya Microfinance Group gets together every two weeks in the Montecristi canton, known for its rich, pre-colonial culture and for its world renown handicrafts, such as the famous toquilla straw (Panama) hats.

This is where we met Maria, a 27-year-old single woman who rents an apartment with her cousin and is currently earning a certificate from the Laica Eloy Alfaro de Manabí University while working at a private school. She has been in the group for four loan cycles, and she likes it because she is able to both finance her business and get ahead with these loans.

She sells Yanbal products (beauty products, cosmetics, fragrances, and women's fashion jewelry). She works every day from 8:30am until 1:00pm at the school and in the afternoon, she walks around town selling and delivering products, as well as billing customers because she gives them credit and gets paid weekly. She has been in business for seven years, and her most popular products are cosmetics and fragrances.

She will use this loan to purchase fragrances, fashion jewelry, cosmetics, lotions, and other products. She dreams of finishing her studies.

loans.use: Purchase fragrances, lotions, cosmetics, fashion jewelry, etc.

loans.name: Polad

texts.en: Polad I. is a 39-year-old man who lives in the southern part of Azerbaijan, an area called Bilasuvar. He is an IDP (Internally Displaced Person), who fled to Bilasuvar during the war in 1993. Polad is a diligent man and works very hard to cover all his family's needs. He has been raising animals for many years. He sells dairy products to the local bazaar traders and neighbours. Currently he has one calf and one milker cow. His poor financial situation has prevented him from buying a calf to expand his cattle-breeding business. Therefore, he has applied to Aqroinvest and Kiva for a loan. He used this loan to buy two more cows.

loans.use: to buy two cows

loans.name: Dariyka's Group

texts.en:
Dariyka S., 43, is the treasurer of this group. She resides in Kochkor and together with her husband, a tractor driver, brings up four children.  Their oldest child is getting ready to graduate from high school. 

Dariyka’s husband is currently repairing his tractor and is getting ready for field work. In the winter, he breeds and sells livestock and Dariyka helps him take care of them.  Currently, the couple is finishing the construction of their house using the revenue from their business.  They plan to spend part of this loan on purchasing the fuel needed for the sowing process, and part of it on purchasing sheep or bulls for their livestock business. 

         --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock and fuel

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine N. is 28 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is single and has three children.  Two of her children are currently in school.  Catherine has a beauty salon, which she has had for two years.  She also has a second business: rental houses.  

To help expand her business, Catherine has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase oil and braids for the hair for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Catherine hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children.  In the future, Catherine hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase oil and braids for the hair for resale.

loans.name: Jean De Dieu

texts.en:
Jean De Dieu, age 32 and married, has owned a motorcycle transport business for the past twelve years. His business is well-organized and open daily from 6 a.m. until 8 p.m. 
  
Jean De Dieu has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to buy essential materials like tires for his motorcycle transport. With the profits, he plans to reinvest in his business and to save for his future.

loans.use: to buy essential materials like tires for his motorcycle transport

loans.name: Elcira Pepita

texts.es:
Elcira  tiene 53 años de edad,  tiene 7 hijos los cuales ya son independientes  ella vive con su esposo en una localidad de Coretal II, en  el distrito de Guadalupe, en la Libertad.

Elcira cuenta  con una pequeña bodega instalada en su domicilio la cual atiende ella misma.   Allí ella ofrece a sus vecinos y clientes de la zona productos lácteos, haci como también productos de primera necesidad , abarrotes, frutas y gaseosas que le genera ingresos para sus gastos framiliares.   El negocio cuenta con muy buena acogida, adicionalmente se dedica a la cría de animales menores, especialmente ovejas y aves, en algunos corrales situados cerca a su domicilio los  alimenta de granos y pastos naturales, cuando ya han alcanzado un buen nivel de desarrollo los ofrece en venta a los negociantes que frecuentemente visitan la zona en donde reside.

Ella desea adquirir alimentos balanceados para sus aves y ovejas, ya que la demanda aumentado en estos últimos tiempos.  Erlita espera obtener mejores resultados en su negocio, por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 3000 nuevos soles.

Ella ayuda a su esposo con el sostenimiento económico de su familia., cuenta con muy buenas referencias, las personas de su localidad la reconocen como una mujer trabajadora y responsable.
texts.en:
Elcira is 53 years old.  She has seven children who all now live independently.  Elcira lives with her husband in Coretal II, in Guadalupe district, in La Libertad.

Elcira has a small grocery store in her home where she works.  She offers her neighbors and local customers dairy products and also basic household products, groceries, fruit and soda which makes her income with which to cover her family expenses.  Her business is very popular.  Elcira also raises animals, especially sheep and birds, in some pens which are located near her home.  She feeds them grain and natural pasture.  When they have reached a good level of development, she offers them for sale to the traders who frequently visit her area.

Elcira would like to acquire balanced feed for her birds and sheep since her demand has increased recently.  She hopes to obtain better results in her business and so has requested a loan for 3,000 Peruvian soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

Elcira helps her husband to financially support their family.  She has very good references.  People from her town recognize her as a hard-working and responsible woman.

loans.use: to acquire balanced feed for her birds and sheep

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.es:
Gregoria nació en la ciudad de Cusco (Perú), tiene 54 años edad y vive en la misma ciudad donde nació, ella está feliz porque está casada y fruto de esta unión tiene dos hijos. (Cusco se caracteriza por tener hermosos paisajes y por ser una zona turística). Ella pertenece al banco comunal María Auxiliadora de la Asociación Arariwa que cada treinta días se reúnen en la casa de una de las socias en el distrito de San Jerónimo de la ciudad del Cusco.   
 
En la reunión del banco comunal conocimos a la señora Gregoria que nos cuenta que ella tiene una pequeña ferretería pero el local es alquilado. Ya son 12 años que se dedica a este negocio y le va muy bien.  En esta oportunidad la socia necesita el préstamo para comprar más mercadería como por ejemplo clavos, fierros, pintura y otras cosas más.
texts.en:
Gregoria was born in the city of Cusco (Perú).  She is 54 years old, and she lives in the same city where she was born.  She is happy because she is married, and they have two children.  (Cusco is known for having beautiful scenery and for being a tourist zone).  She belongs to the María Auxiliadora Communal Bank with the Arariwa Association.  They meet every month in the house of one of the members in the San Jerónimo district in the city of Cusco.

We met Gregoria at the Communal Bank meeting.  She tells us that she has a small hardware store, but she rents the place.  She has worked in this business for 12 years, and it is going very well for her.

She now needs the loan to buy more merchandise like; for example; nails, iron, paint, and other things.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise like; for example; nails, iron, paint, and other things.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace, 42 years old, is currently in the business of selling vegetables. She is married to a farmer and they have six children, none of whom are at school. Her future goal is to build a house.

loans.use: to stock more vegetables.

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en:
Hadija is a married woman with the four children, three of whom attend school while one is still too young for school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water.

For the past year, she has operated a charcoal selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. Her greatest challenge is seasonality. During the rainy season it becomes difficult to supply charcoal for sale. She dreams of expanding and establishing a goat selling business.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for sale. She decided to join Yehu because of its simple procedures and requirements.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Juan Blas

texts.es:
El Sr. Juan es de la ciudad de Santani, tiene 48 años de edad, esta casado con la Sra. Benita de 38 años de edad, Actualmente tienen 2 Hijos, ambos menores de edad.
El Cliente tiene una despensa, por medio del cual puede mantener los gastos de la casa. Se define a si mismo como una persona luchadora y trabajadora, ademas comenta que tener una despensa es muy sacrificado ya que tiene que trabajar de lunes a lunes.
Uno de sus sueños es algún día poder ampliar su negocio y poder tener un pequeño autoservice.
Solicita el credito para la compra de comestibles, lácteos, bebidas, hortalizas y demás, que servirán para mantener surtido su local. Tiene esperanza en el credito, ya que le sera de gran ayuda.
texts.en:
Mr. Juan is from the city of Santini. He is 48 and married to Mrs. Benita, age 38. They currently have 2 children, both young.
He has a store that allows him to cover his household costs. He describes himself as a hard-working person, and also says that having a store is very difficult, since he has to work every day of the week.
One of his dreams is to be able to expand his business one day and have a small autoshop.
He is requesting this loan for the purchase of food items; dairy products, drinks, vegetables and more. This will allow him to maintain his stock. He has high hopes for this loan, as it will be a great help for him.

loans.use: to purchase food items; dairy products, drinks, vegetables and more.

loans.name: Nyakagezi Twetungure Group

texts.en: Agriculture is the major farming activity in Uganda and mostly in the western part of the country with various activities like farming, cattle keeping, poultry and so on. Since Muwamin is a part of the community, she is involved in farming activities, a business she took up several years ago. As a result, she is now able to sell beans, coffee, maize and so on from her farm as well as buying from other farmers for enough stock to sell. She operates from Nyakagezi, selling to residents of the town council and as a result, she is able to make 50,000 shillings as her weekly income. She is a very honest and hard-working lady and she needs a loan to be able to buy more coffee for resale. She is a first-time borrower from Pearl Micro finance and she hopes for the best.

loans.use: To buy more coffee for resale.

loans.name: Soeun

texts.en: Soeun makes a living by building wooden houses. His wife, San, is a farmer and silk weaver. They have been married since 1979 and have four children -- three sons and one daughter. They live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Soeun is applying for a loan for $1,000 to buy pipe and a pump to use on the family's farm.

loans.use: to buy equipment for his family's farm.

loans.name: Bahriniso

texts.ru:
Бахринисо разведена и мать 2 детей. Она честная и целеустремленная женщина. Она сама одна кормит своих детей и ей трудно полностью удовлетворять все потребности своих детей, и она всегда нуждаются в поддержку. С этими трудностями она решила заниматься купля продажей материалов, одежды, обуви, продукты питание и сельскохозяйственных культур. Она ежемесячно ездит в других районах за покупки материалов и обуви, а за продовольственными товарами еженедельно. Бахринисо хотела бы получит кредит в размере 2300$ США для покупки материалов и школьных униформ. Она заранее благодарит всех вас за поддержку и милосердие.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj
texts.en: Bahriniso is a divorced mother of two children.  She is an honest and goal-oriented woman.  She supports her children on her own and has a hard time satisfying all of the needs of her children, and always needs support.  She decided to deal with these difficulties by getting involved in buying and selling materials, shoes, food products and agricultural crops.  She travels monthly to other districts to purchase materials and shoes, and travels weekly to buy food products.  Bahriniso wants to obtain a loan in the sum of $2300 for the purchase of materials and school uniforms.  She thanks everyone in advance for the support and mercy.

loans.use: to purchase materials and school uniforms

loans.name: Urcisina

texts.en:
Urcisina is 62 years old.  She is from the town of Loon, Bohol. She runs a sari-sari store business, selling items such as vinegar and canned goods. She also makes banana chips that she sells to the people in her community.

Urcisina is requesting a loan to buy more items to sell such as soap, shampoo, noodles and canned goods. She will also buy more bananas to make chips. Urcisina hopes to expand her store in the future.

loans.use: buy soap, shampoo, noodles and canned goods

loans.name: Trang

texts.en:
Trang is a 39-year-old married woman living with her husband and two children in Ho Chi Min City. Her husband works as a plumber. 

Trang has been running a coffee shop for 10 years. She plans to use the loan to buy a greater range and quantity of coffee and beverages to sell in her shop.

Trang hopes that through the loan, she will be able to generate additional income to reinvest in her shop and adequately cover her family's living expenses.

loans.use: To buy more coffee and beverages to sell

loans.name: Maria Bellaluz

texts.es:
La señora Maria Bellaluz ha tenido ya un crédito con KIVA el cual fue para la construcción de unos cuartos en la planta alta de su vivienda. 
       Solicita un préstamo para invertir en su negocio de venta de perfumes, ya que le están pidiendo mas variedad de perfumes para dama y caballero y cosméticos de belleza, por el momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para realizar la inversión. 
       Daña Maria Bellaluz planea pagar el crédito con las ganancias que obtiene de sus venta, ya que su esposo el señor Fernando se encargara de los gastos familiares y escolares de sus hijos con el sueldo que recibe como oficial escolar de la ciudad. 
Espera contar con su cooperación en este préstamo, ya que desea mejorar sus ventas para poder ayudar a su esposo y darles a sus hijos una mejor vida y educación.
texts.en:
Maria Bellaluz has already received a loan from KIVA which she used to build some rooms on the upper floor of her home.  She is requesting this loan to invest in her business selling perfumes as her customers are requesting a greater range of men's and women's perfumes and beauty products.  Right now, she doesn't have the money she needs to make this investment.

Maria Bellaluz plans to repay her loan with the profits that she makes from her sales as her husband, Fernando, will take care of their family expenses and the education expenses of their children with the salary that he earns working as a school official in the city.

Maria Bellaluz hopes that she can count on your cooperation in this loan as she would like to improve her sales so that she can help her husband and provide her children with a better life and education.

loans.use: to buy merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy pigs to feed and sell.

loans.name: Lucia Del Transito

texts.es:
Lucia, vive con su hija y un nieto, es casada, trabaja como maestra de la escuela y administradora y dueña de una tienda, quien la atiende su hija a tiempo completo todos los días, en su vivienda.
Ella está solicitando un préstamo para la compra de mercadería como boquitas, dulces, galletas, gaseosas, aceite, pastas y mejoramiento del local, esta compra le ayudara a tener un mayor inventario y a mejorar la atención a los clientes.
La aspiracion de Lucia es aumentar ingresos y mejorar su negocio dando un buen servicio y ademas pagar puntualemnte para ser un buen cliente.
texts.en:
Lucia lives with her daughter and one grandson. She is married and works as a schoolteacher as well as the owner and manager of a store. She runs the store together with her daughter full-time, every day. The store is located in her home. 

She is requesting a loan to buy merchandise such as snacks, sweets, cookies, soft drinks, cooking oil and pasta. She will also improve the store. This purchase will help her have a larger inventory and improve the service she provides to her customers. 

Lucia's aspirations are to increase her income and improve her business, to provide good service, and also to pay off her loan punctually in order to be a good client.

loans.use: to buy snacks, sweets, cookies, soft drinks, cooking oil and pasta.

loans.name: Wilmer

texts.es:
Wilmer tiene 50 años, es un hombre muy trabajador y emprendedor, es soltero y no tiene hijos. Vive en casa de sus padres, en compañía de sus dos hermanos menores, a los quiere y desea ayudar con su educación. La actividad que realiza Wilmer es la venta al por mayor de plátanos. Es así que todas las mañanas se levanta desde muy temprano para dirigirse al Puerto Nro 1, llamado Malecón Grau, en donde espera el arribo de los productores, a quienes compra a precios más cómodos, para luego venderlos a precios más elevados. Tiene tres años dedicándose a ésta actividad, y hasta el momento lo ha hecho solo, pero en ocasiones debe contratar peones para que lo ayuden en la carga de los productos. Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es que le permite tener un ingreso económico, y gracias a ello puede aportar en los gastos de su familia. Este seria el primer crédito con la institución MFP,  se siente muy contento por la oportunidad de contar con una línea de crédito y con un capital de trabajo. Por tanto se compromete en ser puntual en sus pagos para tener acceso a más créditos futuros.
Con el préstamo que solicita, lo invertirá en la compra de plátanos.
texts.en:
Wilmer is 50 years old, single, with no children. He is a very hardworking and enterprising man. He lives in his parents' house, along with his two younger siblings, who he loves and wants to help with their education. Wilmer sells plantains wholesale. Every morning he arises very early to get to Puerto Numero 1, also called Malecón Grau, where he awaits the arrival of the producers. He buys the plantains at a good price, and then sells them at higher prices. He has been doing this for three years, and so far he has done it by himself, occasionally hiring workers to help him carry the produce. 

What he likes about his work is that it allows him to have a modest income, thanks to which he can help with the family expenses. This will be his first loan with MFP, and he is very happy for the opportunity to have a line of credit and working capital. Therefore he promises to be punctual in his payments so he will be eligible for more loans in the future. With the requested loan he will purchase plantains.

loans.use: to purchase more plantains

loans.name: Maileen

texts.en:
Maileen is 32 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 2 children. 
Maileen has a shop that makes & sells snacks like pancakes & banana cues. She has had this business for 5 years. She requested a loan of PHP 7,000 to buy raw ingredients for making snacks.
Maileen has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Maileen hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for making snacks

loans.name: Shahida's Group

texts.en:
Shahida is requesting for a loan from KIVA partner Asasah for her husband’s grocery store business. With the loan investment, he will buy grocery stock in bulk quantity such as spices, sugar, cooking oil, snacks, etc. This will allow for better customer service in his store and increase his profits and sales.

He is very fair in his rates and treats his clients very respectfully. Shahida has a lot of confidence in her husband and very certain that he will make good use of loan and successfully increase his profits.

Shahida is a housewife and performs her household tasks by staying at home. She is very good in nature and tries to provide comfort to her family with her efforts.

She has given birth to four sons. Two of them work in private organizations while other two are studying.

She is very confident of her husband’s business success after the loan investment and hopeful that it will help her family build a better financial life.

Note: In the photo, the lady holding a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Shahida.

loans.use: to buy cooking oil, spices, snacks, sugar and other grocery items for a grocery store business

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en: Harriet is 41 years old and lives in the town of Hoima, Uganda. She is widowed and has three children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past three years, she has worked hard at her bar, where she sells soda and beer. To help expand her business, Harriet has applied for a loan for 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. She will use the loan to buy more soda and beer to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to buy food to feed her family. In the future, Harriet hopes to build rental houses. She is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP), which primarily serves small entrepreneurs who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that are too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more crates of soda and beer to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Nan

texts.en:
Nan (pictured here) is single and lives with her brother and sisters and widowed father in a small village across the Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Her father is a farmer and raises cows at home. 


Nan is a garment worker. She is applying for a loan in the amount of $400 to help her sister who is a weaver by purchasing weaving materials.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials for her sister’s weaving business.

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia is 52 years old and married with three children. She lives at Cabatuan. Her primary source of income is raising hogs. Lilia is busy with her schedule of cleaning and feeding the hogs three times a day. She decided to establish her business to generate income instead of just lazing at home and doing household chores. 

Lilia is requesting a 27,000 PHP loan to buy vitamins, vaccines, and feed to nourish her hogs. She currently lacks sufficient funds. Lilia wants to expand her business in the future and hopes this loan will be granted as it is her only chance to improve her business and her family’s life.

loans.use: to buy vitamins, vaccines, and feed

loans.name: Lelyn Arminda

texts.es:
Lelyn, de 41 años de edad, estudio hasta sexto grado, es madre soltera y vive solo con sus dos hijas en la casa de su madre, las dos van a la escuela.

Lelyn, desde hace diez años se ha dedicado al negocio de venta de hamburguesas, tacos, tortas y refrescos, su madre la incentivo para que colocara este pequeño negocio, puesto ella también tiene un puesto de tacos y lo iniciaron debido a la necesidad de obtener ingresos para mantener a su familia, el negocio lo tiene cerca de la casa y el horario de atención es de 5:00 a.m. a 5:00 p.m. 
 
Lelyn, necesita el préstamo para comprar carne, pan para hamburguesas, salsas, verduras y bebidas para su negocio, porque en está temporada se vende más.

Lelyn, sueño con tener su negocio y con el tiempo lograr tener un restaurante en un lugar más adecuado y grande para sus clientes.

loans.use: para comprar carne, pan para hamburguesas, salsas, verduras y bebidas para su negocio.

loans.name: Adoudé Mercy

texts.en:
Mrs Adoudé Mercy A. A. was born in 1968. Married and the mother of two (2) children, she also has charge of her sick mother. For that last 8 years, she has operated a business producing and selling palm oil - a very popular oil used for cooking in her town. This has allowed her to contribute to running of her household with her modest income. The production and stocking of palm oil requires enough money. It is necessary to first buy the palm nuts before making the oil. This preparation also requires wood for burning and a lot of care and precision. It is meticulous work. To store the oil, one needs to buy drums. Palm oil is a much loved part of Togolese cuisine and her business is flourishing. Mrs A. A. is asking for a loan of $600 to improve her production and satisfy her ever increasing clientele.

Translated from French by Susan Bell, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame A. A. Adoudé Mercy est née en 1968. Mariée et mère de deux (2) enfants, elle a à sa charge sa mère malade. Depuis 8 ans, elle exerce le commerce d’huile de palme (huile très utilisée pour la cuisine dans sa localité). Ce qui lui permet de contribuer aux charges du ménage avec son revenu, aussi modeste soit-il. La production et le stockage d’huile de palme nécessitent assez de fonds. Il faut d’abord s’approvisionner en noix de palme avant de faire la préparation. Cette préparation nécessite également de bois de chauffe et se fait avec beaucoup de soins et de précision. C’est un travail méticuleux. Pour le stockage, il faut des bidons qu’il faut aussi acquérir. L’huile de palme est une denrée très appréciée dans les préparations culinaires togolaises et son commerce est florissant. Madame A. A. sollicite un crédit de $600 pour pouvoir améliorer sa production et satisfaire sa clientèle qui croît de jour en jour.

loans.use: purchase of palm nuts for the preparation of palm oil

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela and her husband live on a farm in Baba, Ecuador where they cultivate rice. She has two children who are already grown up, but still live with her and help out on the farm. They have a few chickens and pigs that are their secondary sources of income. Angela hopes to invest the loan in a water pump so she may access water for her crops.

Communal Banking in Baba

This borrower is part of the newest and largest Communal Bank in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Baba Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in the county of Baba in rural Ecuador. Their association works cooperatively to cultivate rice and commercialize the product after it has grown. As an association, Centro Agricola helps the farmers by providing access to machinery and training services. The farmers from Centro Agricola have received special instruction on financial responsibility and accounting from Codemicro, an organization that specializes in training programs geared towards the rural sector.

The members of Centro Agricola de Baba will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others' guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Centro Agricola de Baba Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program.

Economy of Baba

The people of Baba have been organized since the days of Gran Colombia when Ecuador was yet to be a country. The area has always been popular because of the extremely productive lands that gave way to cultivation of cacao for decades. Now Baba is a county in the province of Los Rios in the coastal region of Ecuador. For most of the latter part of the 20th Century it was a cacao and banana-producing sector. Most of the surrounding areas of Baba in Los Rios are owned by large multinational companies such as Dole, but Baba is a sector characterized by small and informal farms.

Rice production has now turned into the main economic activity of the sector as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Cacao is still very popular in the area, but because of the long cultivation cycle people prefer to invest in rice. The lands in Baba are very fertile though, and most farmers in the sector often grow other crops, such as plantains and soybeans as secondary sources of income. Many farmers also keep livestock as emergency sources of food and income, commonly resorting to selling a chicken or pig if they are in need of cash.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Baba area are small farmers. They produce about 80 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds, plowing and leveling the lands. This is the most difficult part for the farmers in Baba, who often lack the necessary machinery to properly plow the lands for rice production. After appropriately preparing the lands, the farmers fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water-intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production.

Access to Credit

One of the biggest struggles in the area has been the lack of credit due to the absence of any type of financial institution. Because people do not count on formal financial finance, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Risks

The largest risk in the sector is due to absence of watering systems. Although Baba is in the province “Los Rios” (the rivers) there is severe problem with access to water. The lack of infrastructure in the sector does not allow the small farmers to benefit from the presence of the many rivers in the area. If the winter season is too dry, it is likely that the lands will not be sufficiently fertile for rice production in the summer. On the other hand, if there is too much rain, there are not any drainage systems to prevent flooding and the crops are often ruined. Generally speaking though, Baba is a very productive sector where the lands yield all types of crops including rice, cacao, corn, watermelons, plantains, and soybeans.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will mostly be used to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. Many clients will use the capital towards renting machinery and equipment necessary to effectively work and prepare the fields. Clients also typically use a part of the loan to buy livestock in order to raise and have as reserves. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical micro-entrepreneur because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures. Mifex asks our rural clients only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Angela hopes to invest in a water pump to water her rice crop

loans.name: Jose Patrocinio

texts.en:
My name is José G.. I am a corn miller. I've owned my business for 3 years, and it is going very well because in order to make tortillas, one first has to grind the corn to produce dough. Tortillas are a basic food staple in our community and business is going well. At this moment I need to perform maintenance on the motor which forms the core of my business.

With the profits that I will have, I want to buy another corn grinding machine to be able to serve all of my customers; the demand is high and most importantly, it allows me to provide for my family.

Translated from Spanish by Ramón F. Kolb, Kiva Volunteer.

Mi nombre es Jose G. me dedico a moler maiz, tengo mi negocio hace 3 anos, el cual es muy bueno porque para hacer tortillas hay que moler el maiz para hacer la masa, y como las tortillas son un alimento primordial en nuestra comunidad este es buen negocio, en estos momento necesito darle mantenimiento a mi motor que es el corazon de mi negocio, con las ganancias que obtenga poder comprar otro moledor de maiz para atender todos mis clientes porque la demanda es grande y lo mas importante alimentar mi familia.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for the motor, water, and oil.

loans.name: Sotuk

texts.ru:
Sotuk YU., 52 is married and is a mother of 5 children. She has a high school education. For a few years, her husband has been working in Russia as a seasonal laborer. Sotuk’s children are all grown up. The two younger ones are helping their mother to sell (one of Sotuk’s daughters is on the photo). The older children have their own families. Sotuk has been in sales business for 5 years. She became a MicroInvest client in 2005. Then, all her business assets were worth $350. Before Sotuk learned about MicroInvest, she took out high-interest short-term loans from illegal local loan sharks. Gradually, with careful investment of the borrowed funds, Sotuk increased the variety of sold items. She also began to travel and purchase goods herself. Sotuk’s quality of life improved. She became an experienced borrower. Today, her business assets have grown four times to $1500. She now plans to open her own wholesale store.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Юсуфова Сотук- 52года. Замужем, мать пятерых детей. Образование среднее специальное. Муж уже несколько лет в России на заработках. Дети взрослые, двое младших помогают матери в торговле, у остальных своя отдельная семья. Опыт работы в торговле продуктов питания 5лет. Начала кредитоваться в МЗФ «Микроинвест» с 2005года, тогда её активы составляли 350$. До того как она была информирована о программе «Микроинвест» она брала краткосрочные кредиты с большой процентной ставкой у местных нелегальных кредиторов. Постепенно после активного использования займа она расширила наименования товара и кроме того сдала ездить за товаром сама. Изменилось уровень жизни, и стала информированной опытной заемщицей. Сейчас её активы достигли до 1500$. В будущем планирует открыть собственный оптовый магазин. P. S-На фото её дочь

loans.use: To open a wholesale store

loans.name: Shahnaz

texts.en:
I am a textile designer and my husband is a plumber. Together, we earn $140 USD a month, which is too little to support our four children. But even then, we have somehow managed to send our children to school.

I could not study, but I do not want my children to be educated. In order to manage the school expenses and the everyday household expenditures, I need to expand my knitting business for which I require to buy a large amount of wool. The wool should preferably be a wool bale. Thus, I am requesting a loan of 175 USD.

loans.use: To buy wool in bulk

loans.name: Karina Elizabeth

texts.es:
Karina started helping her mom at a seamstress shop two years ago, because her mom had many orders and could not fulfill all of them. That is how her interest in this type of business started. Little by little Karina got clients who want her to make clothes for them, and so, two sewing machines provide Karina's livelihood.

Karina is very hopeful to be able to get married and have children to teach them how good life can be when one works hard. She also wants to help her mother with the household expenses because her mom cannot do much sewing anymore because this work hurts her back. This is why Karina is requesting a loan for US$1,100 to be paid in a period of 6 months. With this money, Karina will be able to buy a new sewing machine and so she will finish her jobs more quickly, because one of the sewing machines she has is now very old and it takes a long time to sew an article of clothing. With your help, Karina will be able to help her mom and save money to get married.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer

Karina comenzó a ayudarle a su mamá hace dos años, en un taller de costura, puesto que su mamá tenía muchos pedidos y no podía sacarlos todos. Y fue así como comenzó por interesarse en este tipo de negocios. Y poco a poco fue haciéndose de clientas que quieren que les fabrique ropa. Y con dos máquinas de coser es con lo que vive Karina.

Karina está muy ilusionada por poder en un futuro casarse y tener hijos para enseñarles los bueno que es la vida si se trabaja duro. Y también desea ayudar a su mamá con los gastos del hogar, puesto que ya no puede mucho con la costura, porque este oficio molesta mucho la espalda. Por lo tanto está solicitando un crédito de US $1,100 para pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Karina podrá comprar una nueva máquina de coser para terminar más rápido sus trabajos. Puesto que una de las que tiene está ya muy viejita y tarda mucho en coser una prenda. Con tu ayuda Karina podrá ayudar a su mamá y juntar dinero para poder casarse.

loans.use: Buying a sewing machine to sew clothing more quickly.

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Water, water everywhere, but not a cold drop to drink.  In 2004, Anna W. established a business selling bottled water and has realized that she could increase her sales if she were able to refrigerate the water.  She is therefore requesting a loan of $625 to purchase a fridge.  Anna is a 37 year-old single mother with one son, Ibnrahim, who is 17.  She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing.  Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets.  This leads to poor financial support, which in turn leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys from and leases equipment to women.  Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from the said client extending a loan to her, and then leases back the same equipment – a process called a "sale and leaseback arrangement".

loans.use: To purchase a refrigerator to chill the water she sells.

loans.name: Ferzaga

texts.en: N. Ferzaga is a 54-year-old man who breeds cattle for meat production. He has bred and sold them to the local bazaar traders for four years. Meat is very popular, being eaten almost everyday throughout Azerbaijan. Ferzaga is married with three children, and because his income does not cover his family's needs, he has applied for 1200 USD to purchase three calves at an estimated cost of 300 USD each, with the remaining money to be used for the purchase of fodder.

loans.use: To purchase three calves and fodder

loans.name: Chanthol

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthol S. lives on the way to Ankor Wat, approximately eighteen kilometers form Phnom Penh. She was married in 1984 to Bauy Ty. They have five sons and three daughters. Three of their children have full time employment and the others are studying in in local school.

Mrs. S. and her husband have had a vegetable garden for 24 years. They sell the produce in a market in Phnom Penh. They are polite and friendly and wish to set up a grocery store for their daughter to sell food in the village market.

Mrs. S. is requesting her third loan in the amount of $500. She will use this money to increase the vegetable production in the family's garden.

loans.use: To purchase additional vegetable plants

loans.name: Un

texts.en:
Mrs. Un P., age 29, is a mother of two children. She works as a weaver and makes $6 a day on average. Her husband Mr. Kim Vy, age 30, works as a construction worker building house. He earns around $3 a day. They have two children, both of whom are students.

This couple wants a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike to commute to work. This will allow them to save a lot of money.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting to work.

loans.name: Agha Gul

texts.en: Agha Gul lives with his own family in district 4 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is uneducated and he works in agriculture. He wants to improve his business but he doesn't have the means to do so at present so he wants to take a loan. He has requested an individual loan to complete his stock and buy more seeds for his land to make good income so that he can offer his children a better education. He is happy that people can help him solve his problem with this process of small loans in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, etc.

loans.name: Linda

texts.en: Linda A. manufactures palm oil in Ghana from palm fruit.  Most Ghanaians use palm oil for preparing stew, and also in the preparation of soap.  Therefore, Linda has many customers and is able to contribute to her family's income.  She is married and has 5 children.  However, the major challenge to her business now is the increase in the price of palm fruit.   To overcome this challenge, she is requesting a loan of $225 to buy larger quantities of palm fruit and other ingredients for the production of oil.

loans.use: To buy more palm fruit and other ingredients for the production of palm oil.

loans.name: Illimani Group

texts.es:
This is the third time the Illmani group has applied for loans, so most of them know the process well. This time they only have 3 new members. Their president Mrs Genara is very outgoing and this is one of the oldest groups in the institution. Their costs range from between 1000Bs - 3300 Bs. The most that they have given was to Ingrid, and they can only give money to members of the institution. In this new cycle they hope to meet everyone's needs and all the members promise to respect and conform to the rules of the credit cycle. The women live in the neighbourhood of Sensata which is where they have their meetings. The women all work in different roles, such as selling food, clothes and clothing articles, fruit and other things. They do this responsibly and the group is very ethical which is why they have high hopes for this cycle.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

El grupo Illimani esta ya en su tercer ciclo, es por esto que ya se conocen muchos D. los componentes, en esta ocasión solamente se cuenta con tres nuevos a los que se les recomendó marchar al ritmo D. la asociación. Su presidenta la Sra. Genara esta muy animada ya que serian unos D. los grupos más antiguos dentro D. la institución. Los montos oscilan entre los 1000 Bs. Y los 3300 Bs. El monto mayor se le dio a la Sra. Ingrid, y según los informes D. central D. riesgos solamente sería cliente D. nuestra institución. En el nuevo ciclo se espera cumplir con todas las disposiciones del grupo, ya que todos los componentes se comprometieron a respetar y cumplir las reglas del ciclo D. crédito. Las señoras pertenecen al barrio D. Sensata, misma zona donD. se realizan las reuniones, las señoras son trabajadoras en diferentes rubros como la venta D. comidas, venta D. ropas y artículos D. vestir, venta D. frutas y otros. Estas actividades la realizan con responsabilidad, y existe bastante solvencia moral en el grupo por lo que se espera acabar el presente ciclo con las mejores expectativas.

loans.use: Capital for operations/CAPITAL DE OPERACIONES

loans.name: Teresa Mercedes

texts.es:
Ms. Teresa belongs to the bank Banco Comunal Las Azucenas. She lives in Jr. Contamana #183, District of Yarina Cocha, Department of Ucayali. She’s 52 years old and she has 5 children. Her husband is an electrician. With the first Manuela Ramos loan of S/.300 (300 soles, Peruvian currency) received, she decided to purchase Unique and Avon brand cosmetics. AsiD. from selling cosmetics, she makes additional income as a fast food street vendor in the evenings, selling items such as salchipapas (a potato and sausage dish and sandwiches). Her business is doing well. With this 1,800 Soles loan, which will be repaid in 4 moths, she will stock her business, buy a display case for her cosmetics, purchase perfumes, deodorants, cologne, talcum powders, jewelry, etc. Teresa is very happy with the loan she received since it helped her business grow, in this way reaching her goals and dreams. Teresa wants to sell cards and cell phones. In this ways she will be able to pay for her children’s education especially for one of her children who is studying at university.

Translated from Spanish by Sandy Juárez, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Teresa pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Azucenas, vive en el Jr. Contamana #183, del Distrito D. YarinaCocha del Departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 52 años y es madre D. 5 hijos, su esposo es Electricista. Con el primer préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 300 decidió invertir en la compra D. productos D. belleza D. las marcas Unique y Avon. Ademas D. la venta D. productos D. belleza, por las noches también tiene otro ingreso adicional, ella venD. comida rápida en forma ambulante, como por ejemplo salchipapas y sandwich’s. Le está yendo bastante bien. Con este préstamo D.
